name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 26 March 2020.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President, Mr President, good morning to all the Members present, but also to all those who follow us with remote connections. I would like, at the beginning of the debate, to express a thought, together with you, the victims of the Coronavirus, their families and their loved ones. In addition, I would like to send all sick people our best wishes for a speedy recovery.  At the moment, our health workers are at the forefront of the fight against this virus and deserve all our support, admiration and gratitude for the work they are doing and for the generosity that distinguishes them by operating in often dramatic situations. And our thoughts go, of course, to all the volunteers, the health professionals and the people who are bringing their support to those in need. I have said it and I repeat, the humanity of our citizens is the greatest wealth we have.  I would also like to thank all those workers who keep our societies, farmers, employees, all those who work in telecommunications, security workers, armed forces, supermarket cashiers, line technicians who allow us to make connections, to call and to be close.  Many people, all active in their different fields of competence, who with discipline and a sense of responsibility have not given up: all of them naturally go our thanks.  Nor should we forget all those citizens who make a difference by simple gestures, respecting preventive measures, buying food for an elderly neighbour, perhaps calling them isolated friends, taking care of the most fragile people. Small gestures of concrete solidarity, as our Parliament has also wanted to do by opening its kitchens to prepare 1 000 meals a day for the homeless and volunteers: 100 vulnerable women will be housed in our premises in Brussels. But also in Strasbourg, in Luxembourg, we gave the authorities the willingness to use Parliament's premises for emergency-related activities.  These are the cities that host us, to which we owe a great deal of gratitude, and I would like to greet the citizens of Brussels, Strasbourg and Luxembourg with you to say that it will soon be nice to meet again and continue to work together for the European Union. Parliament's initiatives have been marked by an emergency. I confess that I have found myself taking difficult initiatives, but I have always supported and encouraged all the political groups, no one excluded, and the advice of so many Members. Of course, parliament's functionality would not have been possible without the extraordinary support of our staff and our administration which, with courage and a sense of duty, has been present, and of all the Directors-General. I would like to ask the Secretary-General to extend our gratitude to the workers who are perhaps the most hidden, the cleaning women, the security men, and all those on the staff of our Directorates-General who have made it possible to make the decisions we have taken operational.  Every effort, including that of keeping Parliament open and functioning, with all its bodies, must show that we, the institutions, are capable of caring for people, that we want to make our values live in the emergency too, that democracy does not stop.  These are difficult times and much more will have to be done, including a profound reflection on the society in which we will find ourselves after this difficult season. But the European Union is already fully committed to meeting the needs of citizens and Member States, in their interests, in their common interest and during this crisis, and then we will be even more so, because we want to emerge from this crisis stronger, stronger and better able to face tomorrow the challenges that the global world will present to us. The European Union is acting to support health systems, to make medical products and essential medicines available, to support research, to help and preserve jobs, to support families and the poorest, and to provide aid to farmers, fishermen, entrepreneurs and workers. Only together can we achieve results for the good of our citizens, and that is also why it will be of the utmost importance to coordinate the gradual elimination of containment measures and the way out of the crisis.  We take on the appeal of the European Commission – and I thank the President for her presence – for an orderly and coordinated exit from the emergency to avoid return effects that could be devastating. It is particularly important to keep our democracies alive and to listen to our citizens. As their elected representatives, we shall be debating and voting in this session on a resolution which is very the coordinated action of the European Union to combat the pandemic and its consequences, together with other urgent measures.  Our commitment is to give guidance on the best measures to be taken and to indicate the necessary funds to make as many resources available to the Member States as possible. We must be ambitious because our citizens, the citizens of Europe, are waiting for rapid responses to resume their lives. We are the voice of the citizens and we must be proud and proud, at this time, to contribute with discipline to being useful in building a better future for our peoples.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: At the last meeting of the Conference of Presidents on Thursday 2 April, I decided, together with the leaders of the political groups, to convene Parliament for the extraordinary part-session today and tomorrow, 16 and 17 April, in order to vote on the Commission's new measures to tackle COVID-19 and to discuss and update the European Parliament's position on how to combat the pandemic and its consequences. The revised provisional calendar for 2020 is available on the Plenary webpage.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I would like to inform you that I have received ten requests for urgent procedures, pursuant to Rule 163 of the Regulation, to add the following legislative and budgetary documents related to the COVID-19 emergency to be adopted during the current plenary: Regulation amending the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework Draft amending budget no. 1/2020 Draft amending budget No 2/2020 Mobilisation of the flexibility instrument for 2020 - 2020/2053(BUD) Mobilisation of the flexibility instrument for 2020 - 2020/2056(BUD) Mobilisation of the margin for unforeseen events in 2020 Measures specific measures to address the COVID-19 epidemic Specific measures to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 epidemic in the fisheries and aquaculture sector Medical devices Therefore , following consultations with the political groups, I would like to submit to the House the following proposals for amendments to the final draft agenda: Statements by the European Council and the Commission on coordinated EU action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences: The debate will take place from 9.00 to 12.00. The schedule of voting rounds for Thursday 16 April and Friday 17 April is as follows: THURSDAY The first round of voting will be open from 9.30 a.m. to 10.30 a.m., with votes on these urgent procedures and the first block of amendments to the joint motion for a resolution on coordinated EU action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences. The results of the first round of voting are scheduled to be announced at 1.30 p.m. The second round of voting will be open from 1.30 p.m. to 2.30 p.m., with a vote on the Regulation amending the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework and on the second block of amendments to the joint motion for a resolution on coordinated EU action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences. The results of the second round of voting are scheduled to be announced at 5.00 p.m. The third round of voting will be open from 17.00 to 18.00, with votes on the third block of amendments to the joint motion for a resolution on coordinated EU action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences. The results of the third round of voting are scheduled to be announced at 8.30 p.m. The fourth round of voting will be open from 8.30 p.m. to 9.30 p.m., with votes on the fourth block of amendments to the joint motion for a resolution on coordinated EU action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences. The results will be announced at 10.50 p.m., with the sitting closed at 11.00 p.m. FRIDAY The sitting will be open at 09.00, with the first round of voting from 09.00 to 10.00 and voting on amendments to: Draft amending budget No 1/2020 and Draft amending budget No 2/2020, Two documents on mobilising the flexibility instrument for 2020, The document on mobilising the margin for unforeseen events, Three codecision documents on the "Corona Package II" and Medical devices. The results are expected to be announced at 12.30 p.m. The second round of voting will be open from 12.30 p.m. to 1.30 p.m., with final votes on: Draft amending budget No. 1/2020 and Draft Amending Budget No 2/2020, Two documents on mobilising the flexibility instrument for 2020, The document on mobilising the margin for unforeseen events, Three codecision documents on the "Corona Package II", Medical devices, Joint Resolution on coordinated EU action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences The announcement of results is scheduled for 4.00 pm. A third round of voting, on amendments or final vote on a subsequent motion for a resolution on COVID-19, could possibly take place from 4.00 p.m. to 5.00 p.m., with the results announced at 7.30 p.m. A fourth round of voting, on amendments or final vote on a subsequent motion for a resolution on the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences, could possibly take place from 7.30 pm to 8.30 pm, with the results announced at 10.30 p.m.  The sitting would be closed at 11.00 p.m. The amendment is thus approved. Before we begin the debate, I would like to inform you that at 9.30 a.m. I will open the first voting time. Voting time will be open from 9.30 a.m. to 10.30 a.m. All votes today will be by roll call. Members will be able to check their vote and the results of the vote themselves in the document to be published today on the plenary website.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the European Council and Commission statements on coordinated EU action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences (2020/2616(SRR)).

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: President of the European Council. Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for giving me the opportunity to speak in a debate which is essential because it brings European democracy to life, even when we are faced with circumstances of unprecedented character and exceptional character.  As you have done, I would also, of course, like to address my first words in support of those who, directly or indirectly, are affected by this crisis, by this virus which is hitting Europe but which is also hitting the world. And, as you have done, also express our thanks, our gratitude for all the citizens, all the citizens, especially at the European level, who are mobilised to accept such exceptional restrictions on freedoms so fundamental and so basic, which directly affect the intimacy of each and every one of us.  You also tell you that, in a moment like this, there can be no doubt, the slightest hesitation: the only possible option is to stick together between citizens, between countries, with all the regions in the world. This is the basis for the determination and action that we, the European institutions, must mobilise with each other. So I would like to share with you some of the information to show how, at the outset of the European Council, with the Member States, we are also trying to take on a number of responsibilities. Three European councils held by videoconference were devoted to this coronavirus crisis and this ambition to try to improve, day after day, the way in which actions are coordinated, the way we cooperate between European countries. You understood that the first ambition, when we measured the scale of this crisis, was to work to reduce the spread of the virus and thus to encourage action, with border restrictions, which have an impact on the functioning of the European Union, especially the internal market, with also the mobilization to try to support our researchers. , to ensure that we can be mobilized on vaccines, on therapies.  It is in this sense that, in the context of the G7 and the G20, in full cooperation with the European Commission, we are trying to mobilise efforts, to encourage - through, for example, a donor conference - a mobilization so that we can, as soon as possible, be able to hold scientific solutions through vaccine and therapies. To be very concrete and very direct, the last European Council gave a dual mandate to the President of the Commission and the President of the European Council: to work on a Road Map that addresses both the formulation of recommendations, principles of good practice, to encourage maximum coordination between European countries when we can gradually enter the exit phase , the strategy of phasing out these restrictive measures which had to be decided by most European countries with varying intensities, but still an approach that is in fact similar. The second part of the mandate is to propose to the Heads of State and Government a common joint strategy in order to be able to gradually, in the short, medium and long term, develop a strategy for economic recovery and, I would also like to say, economic transformation. Because I am convinced, like many, that we will have to learn all the lessons from this crisis and see how we can also ensure that tomorrow there will be more strength, more efficiency, more cooperation, more capacity to work together. I would like to share with you what are, in my opinion, the four chapters for which it is very important to open the debate and try to take some decisions, to take steps together. The first priority, in my opinion, in order to succeed in such a recovery strategy is certainly the single market: how is it possible to repair the single market as soon as possible? But it is not only that: it's also how is it also possible to strengthen, to deepen the single market? Because it's our first strength at the European level and it will be essential to try to consider that the European Green Deal and the digital agenda will be, no doubt - in my opinion - the first priority. It will be a very strong leverage in order to be successful in the next few months, in the next few years. I also think that it will be very essential to build a very strong industrial strategy and also, at the same time, to consider the network of the European SMEs as a very strong pillar. It's important, it's essential to continue to support our SMEs and to give them the possibility to build a strong strategy for the future. I also think that the issue of the circular economy is going to have to be further developed. There are very strong proposals, I know, which have already been debated in the European Parliament, which are announced by the European Commission. Because this strength of the internal market, this ability also to develop the circular economy further, to rely on the digital agenda, on this transformation through climate change also, it must give us the opportunity to have more capacity for strategic independence from the European Union.  It is also for this reason that, in my opinion, the international role of the euro must be taken into account: more strong European assets also contribute to this ability to have this international dimension for the euro. The second important point is, of course, the possibility to develop a very strong strategy in order to invest, to invest massively with the current approach, with a national dimension but also with a European ambition, and it's certain that we will continue all our political efforts in order to reach an agreement on the next European budget. We had the opportunity to discuss a lot in the last two weeks, the last month, about this very difficult topic. But maybe it's a unique opportunity. The next seven years: how is it possible with this European budget, to give some tools, some possibilities in order to develop this strong strategy which we need for our common future? The European Investment Bank is also an instrument that must be used. You know that a few weeks ago, in the proposal for a negobox, before this coronavirus crisis, I had strongly advocated that the European Investment Bank could be increased to increase its leverage and to concentrate on investments. It is certain that, as far as investment is concerned, there is an essential dimension of solidarity, in connection with the internal market, for that matter, because it will be important to guarantee the level playing field and to ensure that all European countries, that all Member States, that all European citizens can be taken with the same ambition to succeed in ensuring that we can meet the challenge we face. The third point I would like to mention, which is also essential to us, is the external action of the European Union. The geopolitical ambition of the European Union is, more than ever, necessary to promote the values to which we deeply believe, to defend the interests that are being tested, as we have seen, particularly in recent weeks.  On this issue of external action, we are very convinced that a very specific focus on the relationship with the African continent is going to be important. I am delighted that we, together with several European leaders, together with several African leaders, have been able to express very, very strong ambitions together.  In the short and medium term, it is a question of further supporting health systems on the African continent, of re-opening this debate on debts that weigh heavily on the capacity of action from the African continent, but also of ensuring that in the medium and long term, one has an ambition of intelligent investment in a partnership of mutual interest with the African continent. , in infrastructure consistent with the digital agenda, in line with the Green Deal, with climate change.  There is, I am totally convinced, a mutual interest, an objective alliance that must be fully mobilised in the coming months and years. Finally, the 4th point I would like to mention is this requirement to ask the question of European governance, to also ask the question of European resilience. How can we, in hindsight, learn from this crisis to be stronger tomorrow, to improve decision-making processes, to improve cooperation processes?  I have the impression that what has been announced - you have discussed it a lot - this conference on the future of Europe will offer, perhaps in the coming weeks in the coming months - when there will be the capacity to really start this ambition - the political space, the democratic space, to enable, not only the European institutions but also the European citizens wherever they come to be involved in this ambition. How do we learn the lessons together?  And finally, it is certain that, within the framework of this ambition to succeed in a transformation strategy, a strategy of recovery, the values that founded this European project, these values of unity, solidarity and freedom must be benchmarks, must be be lighthouses that light the way. Indeed, we must address this crisis, we must address this situation, we have also addressed this ability to raise our heads, to get our heads out of the water, by being fully mobilized on these values that must be highlighted, which must indeed be considered to be central and as driving forces.  So, as you can see, there are many challenges and I think That European history has shown that it is when we are faced with the most difficult, that it is when we think that the obstacle is insurmountable that we often find the resource to stick together, the resource to come together, the resource to be engaged in the field of unity , the resource to be creative.  This is going to be necessary. There is no doubt that there are different sensitivities, opinions and ideas in Europe about what to do in the short and medium and long term. However, I am totally convinced that with optimism, determination and this fierce desire to bring to life this democratic heart of the European Union, to ensure that we can make our institutions work because they guarantee the legitimacy of this European ambition, there will be the capacity to make progress.  In any case, you can count on me, on the European Council, to maintain a close dialogue, Mr President, with your House and with the European Commission. Thank you for this motion for a resolution which, in fact, does define the scope of the work which will have to be implemented in the short, medium and long term. You can count on the European Council, also given the reality of the European Council and the 27 Member States that make up it, to be a stakeholder and to try to move in the right direction.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the continuation of the debate on the European Council and Commission statements on coordinated EU action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences (2020/2616(SRR)).

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: présidente de la Commission. – Monsieur le Président du Parlement, Monsieur le Président du Conseil, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, nous n’avons pas assez de mots pour parler de la douleur de l’Europe et de la souffrance du monde. Nous pensons à toutes les victimes et nous prions pour toutes les familles en deuil. Nous nous promettons de raconter leur histoire, d’honorer leurs vies et leur mémoire. Nous nous souviendrons toujours de chacune d’entre elles. Nous nous souviendrons de Julie, la jeune Française, avec toute sa vie devant elle, et de Yann, l’historien tchèque qui s’est toujours battu pour ses valeurs, ou encore de Gino, le médecin italien retraité qui est revenu sur le terrain pour sauver la vie des autres. Nous nous souviendrons du geste incroyable de Suzanne, en Belgique, qui a laissé son respirateur aux plus jeunes et de l’image de Francis, faisant ses adieux à son frère à travers une fenêtre d’hôpital, en Irlande. Nous nous souviendrons de la jeune maman polonaise qui ne verra pas son bébé grandir et du jeune entraîneur de football espagnol qui ne verra pas son rêve se réaliser.  Nous ne les oublierons jamais, les mères, les pères, les sœurs et les frères, les jeunes et les aînés du nord ou du sud, de l’est ou de l’ouest, les amis et les collègues, les voisins d’à côté et les étrangers de plus loin, ceux qui ont des choses à dire et des choses à voir, ceux sur l’épaule de qui on pleure et de l’amour desquels on dépend. Chacune de ces dizaines de milliers d’histoires brise un petit morceau de notre cœur mais elle renforce aussi notre détermination pour que l’Europe fasse tout son possible pour sauver toutes les vies possibles. You cannot overcome a pandemic of this speed and this scale without the truth. The truth about everything: the numbers, the science, the outlook – but also about our own actions. Yes, it is true that no one was really ready for this. It is also true that too many were not there on time when Italy a needed a helping hand at the very beginning. And yes, for that, it is right that Europe as a whole offers a heartfelt apology. But saying sorry only counts for something if it changes behaviour, and the truth is, too, that it did not take long before everyone realised that we must protect each other to protect ourselves. And the truth is that Europe has now become the world’s beating heart of solidarity. The true Europe is standing up: the one that is there for each other when it is needed the most. The one where paramedics from Poland and doctors from Romania save lives in Italy. Where ventilators from Germany provide a lifeline in Spain. Where hospitals in Czechia treat the sick from France. And where patients from Bergamo are flown to clinics in Bonn. We have seen medical supplies go from Lithuania to Spain and respirators go from Denmark to Italy. In fact, we have seen every piece of equipment go in every direction across Europe, from whoever can spare it to whoever needs it. This makes me proud to be European. Of course, there are still some who want to point fingers and deflect blame. And there are others who would rather talk like populists than tell unpopular truths. To this I say: ‘Stop it – stop and have the courage to tell the truth. Have the courage to stand up for Europe’. Because this Union of ours will get us through. But it will only be as strong tomorrow as we make it today. And if you need inspiration, just look at the way the people of Europe are standing together – with empathy, humility and humanity. And I pay tribute to all of them. To the delivery drivers and the food suppliers. The shopkeepers, the factory packers and the balcony clappers. The companies changing their production lines to make the supplies we urgently need. I pay tribute to the Portuguese volunteers sewing masks for their neighbours, or the seven-year-old Greek pianist who composed an ‘isolation waltz’ to keep people going. Above all else I thank and I pay tribute to our heroes: the medics, the nurses, the careworkers. They are the ones with bruises on their faces and tragic images in their minds. The ones holding the hands of the sick as softly and as lovingly as the families that cannot be there. They are the ones saving our lives and saving our honour. The ones we must protect so that they can protect us all. Und genau darauf konzentrieren wir uns. Deswegen legen wir jetzt einen gemeinsamen Vorrat an medizinischer Ausrüstung an. Deswegen investieren wir gemeinsam in Forschung nach Impfstoffen. Deshalb kümmern wir uns zentral um die Beschaffung der am dringendsten benötigten Güter am Weltmarkt. Und deswegen haben wir ein Team der besten Expertinnen und Experten aus ganz Europa zusammengestellt, die regelmäßig ihr Wissen teilen, das Leben retten kann.  Aus diesem Grund verzichten wir auf Zölle und Mehrwertsteuer bei der Einfuhr von medizinischem Gerät aus Drittstaaten. Und das ist auch der Grund, warum wir Anfang dieses Monats ein einfaches, aber großes Versprechen abgegeben haben: Wir werden jeden verfügbaren Euro, den wir haben, auf jede erdenkliche Weise nutzen, um Leben zu retten und die Lebensgrundlagen der Europäerinnen und Europäer zu schützen. Deswegen haben wir vorgeschlagen, sämtliche noch verfügbaren Mittel des aktuellen Haushalts in ein Notprogramm zu lenken. Dadurch können fast 3 Milliarden Euro direkt dorthin fließen, wo sie gebraucht werden: in neue Beatmungsgeräte und Schutzausrüstung, in mehr Tests und mehr medizinische Hilfe für die Schwächsten, einschließlich derer, die in den Flüchtlingslagern warten.  Deswegen schlagen wir vor, jeden verfügbaren Euro aus den europäischen Struktur- und Investitionsfonds zur Bewältigung der Corona—Krise einzusetzen. Das bedeutet, dass wir volle Flexibilität ermöglichen: Die Mittel können in anderen Regionen eingesetzt werden. Sie können überall eingesetzt werden, wo sie am dringendsten gebraucht werden, unabhängig von den sonst üblichen Schranken wie Kofinanzierung, Zweckbindung oder Obergrenzen. Mit diesem Paket, über das dieses Haus heute abstimmen wird, geht Europa an die Grenzen seiner Möglichkeiten. And the same principle applies to protecting people’s livelihoods. Europe has had economic crises before. But we have never had an economic shutdown like this. Nobody is to blame and everybody will need support. We need unprecedented measures to do this and to make sure our economy is ready to bounce forward as soon as possible. And here again, the truth matters. Europe has done more in the last four weeks than it did in the first four years of the last crisis. We have made our state aid rules more flexible than ever. In the last few days alone, we have approved schemes that will provide EUR 1 billion to Croatian businesses, EUR 1.2 billion for Greek SMEs or EUR 20 million to Portuguese fishermen. There are many more examples I could pick, from Latvia and Estonia to Belgium or Sweden. For the first time in our history, we triggered the full flexibility in the Stability and Growth Pact. Along with bold measures taken by the European Central Bank, this provides unprecedented fiscal and financial power. And last week’s decision by EU finance means a further EUR 500 billion will be available to all of those who need it. As part of this, I urge all Member States to make the most of SURE – the new scheme proposed by the Commission to protect Europeans against the risk of unemployment. It will provide EUR 100 billion to help governments make up the difference if your employer has reduced your hours or if you are self-employed and need support. The beauty of SURE is two-fold. First, it will help those in need to pay their rents, bills or food, and keep other businesses alive in the process. And second, it is the definition of European solidarity. The Member States that can, will put up guarantees so others can support the hardest hit in their countries. As a result of all of this action, Europe’s collective response is well above EUR 3 trillion. This is the most impressive response anywhere in the world. But we know we will need more. A lot more. Because this will be a long haul, and the world of tomorrow will look very different from that of yesterday. I am convinced that Europe can shape this new world if it works together and rediscovers its pioneering spirit. And for this, I want to cite a sentence from the Ventotene Manifesto, written by two of Italy and Europe’s greatest visionaries: Ernesto Rossi and Altiero Spinelli, one of our founding fathers.  Writing from their prison on a remote island, at the height of the war, when all hope of a united Europe seemed lost, they gave us these words of confidence: ‘the moment has arrived in which we must know how to discard old burdens, how to be ready for the new world that is coming, that will be so different from what we have imagined’. Dear friends, this moment has arrived once again. The moment to put behind us the old divisions, disputes and recriminations. To come out of our entrenched positions. The moment to be ready for that new world. To use all the power of our common spirit and the strength of our shared purposes. The starting point for this must be making our economies, societies and way of life more sustainable and resilient. Finding the answers in this new world will require courage, trust and solidarity. And it will need massive investment to jump-start our economies. We need a Marshall Plan for Europe’s recovery, and it needs to be put in place immediately. There’s only one instrument we have that is trusted by all Member States, which is already in place and can deliver quickly. It is transparent and it is time-tested as an instrument for cohesion, convergence and investment. And that is the European budget. The European budget will be the mothership of our recovery. And for that reason, the next seven-year budget must be different to what we have imagined, just as Spinelli said. We will use the power of the whole European budget to leverage the huge amount of investment we need to rebuild the Single Market after corona. We will frontload it so we can power that investment in those crucial first years of recovery. Because this crisis is different from any other one we have known. It is severely hitting completely healthy companies because public life has shutdown. And this is why we will need innovative solutions and more headroom in the MFF so it can unlock massive public and private investment. This will kick-start our economies and drive our recovery towards a more resilient, green and digital Europe. By that, we not only support but reshape our industries and services towards a new reality. It will mean investing in our digital technologies, infrastructure and in innovation, such as 3D printing, to help us to be more independent and make the most of new opportunities. And it also means doubling down on our growth strategy by investing in the European Green Deal. As the global recovery picks up, global warming will not slow down. First-mover advantage will count double and finding the right projects to invest in will be key. A more modern and circular economy will make us less dependent and boost our resilience. And this is the lesson we need to learn from this crisis. Investing in large-scale renovation, renewables, clean transport, sustainable food and nature restoration will be even more important than before. This is not only good for our economies, it is not only good for our environment, but it will reduce dependencies by shortening and diversifying supply chains. And we also need to keep another reality in mind. While the crisis is symmetric, recovery is not. Because not only the virus hits but also the economic shock. Some regions will bounce back and others will have a harder time. And therefore, cohesion and convergence will be more important than ever before. The single market and cohesion policy are the two sides of the same coin. You need both to ensure prosperity across the whole European Union. This is the Europe that I believe can emerge from this crisis. One that does everything it can to protect lives and livelihoods. One that is open to the world but can take care of itself. One that is more resilient, green and digital and that invests in its future together. This is the path to recovery. It will be a long road and the whole world will be trying to find its way. This crisis will likely redefine our politics, our geopolitics and possibly globalisation itself. And in this new world, Europe will need to stick together through thick and thin. And as I look around in our Union and I see all that humanity and that ingenuity, I know that we can and we will do just that. They say a strong soul shines bright after every storm. If we all stand up for Europe today – with courage, trust and solidarity – I know that tomorrow Europe’s soul will shine brighter than ever before. Long live Europe. Vive l’Europe. Lang Leben Europa.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: And now let us listen to the political groups. We also have the possibility of some links with the group chairmen at this stage, we hope that everything will work and that this will also allow us to experiment with new mechanisms which, of course, are all to be tested and invented.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Dear David, dear Charles, dear Ursula, thank you for being physically with us. For the duration of the plague, Parliament cannot close and cannot become a remote institution. Like supermarkets or firefighters, Parliament is an essential service during the pandemic. In times of extraordinary powers for governments, Parliament is the hospital of democracy.  We're here today, but millions of citizens are wondering where we were when all this started. Following Ursula's example, I tell him: we could have acted earlier, we could have acted faster, we could even have acted together. That's why you have to apologize.  European governments and European institutions are not to blame for the plague, but they should have expected it and must have reacted quickly. We didn't do one or the other. So it would be nice if, from here, we apologized and stopped treating the dead elders like war heroes: they are victims.  We were wrong not to give importance to a virus because it came from China and we can make a mistake again if we settle in the certainty that this nightmare will end when summer comes.  In Spain, we learned yesterday that at least 5,000 dead have not been counted — almost all elderly people who died in homes or residences – and that, as more tests are done, more contagious will appear.  We are always wrong when we believe that this virus will go for the best hypothesis; this virus always bets on the worst hypothesis. Now we're making plans as if the virus wasn't coming back in the fall, but what if it comes back? We're assuming that if he comes back he'll weaken it or we'll have a vaccine, but what if we don't have it? The second wave of the 1918 flu was the worst. We assume that Europe has already paid the tribute, but what if it explodes in Africa or explodes in the Middle East? I'm not saying we get to the worst; I ask that, as policy makers, we never rule out the worst.  In China, where it all began, there were 3,300 dead. Spain, with less than 4% of China's population, has already had 18,000 – and we are not counting them all – and Italy, 21,000. If we take into account that Italy and Spain have two of the best health systems in the world, it is pertinent to ask: has China told us the whole truth? What game are we playing?  The four riders of today's Apocalypse are: coronavirus, unemployment, nationalpopulism, and lying—lies kill as much as the virus.  In Europe, plague is killing our parents' generation and we all have a feeling that the Council is treating the issue as usual business as usual. Indeed, Mr President, is the single market the Council's first priority, precisely at this very moment? It seems that some governments come to Brussels just to see how much money they can take, and that others come to Brussels to make sure that others don't take that much money, but that no one comes to worry about all Europeans. Coming to Brussels to defend only national interests is also nationalism, even if our prime ministers do not know. If the fear of death affects us all, if death affects us all, if the virus does not distinguish countries, what is the point of national governments being distinguished affected or killed by their nationalities? Ladies and gentlemen of the Council, we are no longer at the time of Draghi's 'what is needed', but at the time of now or never.  China built a hospital in less time than the Council needs to convene —not to meet, to convene. Does that mean that the Chinese dictatorship is more effective than our democracy? No, it means we're not effective, that's all.  This is the time to show that Europeanism can also be effective, that Europeanism can also be epic, that Europeanism can also be patriotic, that Europeanism can also be human. It's time to prove that borders will never be the solution. If the European Union does not serve to deal with a pandemic affecting the whole continent, what is the European Union for?  Mr President-in-Office of the Council, it is time for now or never. Within the EPP, and among the groups that have signed the Resolution, we have made a great deal of consensus effort. I hope it will set an example for the Council. The European Union represents the great hope with millions of Spaniards affected or killed or sick with the virus, millions of Europeans affected, killed or sick from the virus.  Let's not give the populists the reason. Let's not give the nationalists the reason. Let's not give the reason to liars: Spanish flu killed more by hunger than by fever. Let's not give the virus the reason.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr. President, President von der Leyen, President Michel, let me have the first words of this House for the victims who have died from COVID-19 and also for all those who are now in hospitals, at home, trying to overcome the disease. And a thank you also to so many professionals who these days are risking their lives for others, starting with health workers, but also for state security forces, cleaners, supermarket and pharmacy workers, carriers, farmers, nursing home caregivers... To all of us—because let's not forget that most of them are women—thousands of graces.  Ladies and gentlemen, this is a pivotal moment in our history. This coronavirus pandemic has hit us in a way we couldn't have imagined: our safety, our freedom of movement, our daily lives, we still don't know how they will change. Some things are out of control, it's true, but others depend on us. Let us be clear: it is up to the decisions we make now that Europe will be strengthened or that citizens lose confidence in this project.  While at the beginning of this crisis we saw selfish attitudes and nationalist reactions spontaneously emerge, we have gradually managed to get the European Union to react and implement solidarity measures, because that is why the European Union exists. It was created after World War II, in a time of devastation, to avoid competition between States and ensure that reconstruction gave prosperity to all. We are now living in a time of crisis only comparable to the Great Depression and we need another reconstruction plan comparable to the Marshall plan. An increase in the budget is not enough; it must be a real investment strategy and strengthening strategic sectors to ensure Europe's future. That is why this is the moment when we can and must be ambitious and rebuild Europe on a new basis.  This crisis is highlighting great social inequalities, as well as inequalities between territories. We cannot allow this crisis to open an even greater gap. On the contrary, public policies are needed to ensure that we are all equally protected to succeed.  It's time to strengthen public policy, starting with health. It's time to protect the millions of Europeans who are losing their jobs and who don't know how to make the end of the month or how they're going to be able to pay their rents. It is time for a strong and supportive European economy, and finally to provide the eurozone with all the mechanisms it needs to deal with international financial onslating. This includes, of course, mutualizing a portion of our countries' debt, as we propose with the issuance of reconstruction bonds. It is time to renew our economy to be more environmentally friendly and natural resources, and also to digitize it. This crisis has shown us that technology needs to be democratized so that all citizens and businesses, wherever they are, can benefit from it for work, for study, for research, for relationships between people. We are seeing these days how there are many children who, for lack of resources, cannot access the follow-up of online classes, and we must understand that action is needed in this regard.  All these ideas are not new, they have been on the table for some time, such as the European Green Pact or the Eurobonds, which we were already talking about during the 2008 crisis. But now it becomes more urgent than ever; it's time for truth and we can't fail history.  We know what needs to be done, we have put it black on white in the joint resolution which we have been able to negotiate between the four major groups in this Parliament. I would have liked, of course, to join more groups and I hope, in any case, that Members and other members and other groups will join this strong call from the European Parliament for the European Commission and the Council to act.  We know what to do; there is only a lack of political courage to do so and, in this Parliament, we are demonstrating that today we are aware of our historical responsibilities, that we are able to overcome our ideological and national lines to think about the common interest of all Europeans and all Europeans.  In this Resolution we propose urgent and other measures in the medium and long term. All are necessary: the urgent ones to save lives, first of all, but also to create an emergency network that so many people need to survive. The more determined our action is now, the less impact the economic and social crisis will have, the sooner we will go out, and we will all regain normalcy and economic activity sooner.  Indeed, at this time of unity and cooperation of the international community to combat the pandemic, it is regrettable to see how Trump, for example, proposes to stop funding to the World Health Organization, and I believe that in Europe too we must raise this issue and vindicate it.  This is a crisis affecting all the countries of the European Union and we must get all countries out of it with equal strength and determination. It would be unacceptable for COVID-19 to create new inequalities between Member States, thus delaying European convergence.  There are many citizens who are unenchanted with the European Union, but that means they believe in us: they are disappointed because they expect more from us. This is the opportunity we have to show you that it is worth believing in the European Union that the principles of solidarity and justice that we set out are true, and that it is now time to prove it.  If the Commission and the Council did not live up to this crisis, Parliament will now require them to take responsibility. It's not too late, because we have a long way to go. I say to the heads of government in the Council: we are on time, but we do not have a minute to lose. It's our responsibility.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Dear President David Sassoli, dear Charles, dear Ursula and dear colleagues, first of all I want to pay tribute to our health professionals, tired from weeks of fighting COVID-19. The whole of Europe thanks you and, I know, the battle is far from over. Tribute also to all those who demonstrate the strength of our democracy and its ability to face difficult decisions that change the lives of millions of citizens.  The Europe we need is one of solidarity movements, collective creativity and generosity on a daily basis. We are living through difficult times, a test for all of us, but this ordeal, as well as the choices we make, will determine our way of life in a sustainable way. We will build the world from the lessons we learn from this crisis. First, we have a responsibility to learn all the lessons from this health crisis. We are not going to face things better if we do not recognise that at the beginning of this crisis, the withdrawal of the choice of certain Member States and the initial impotence of the Commission left a bitter taste for the citizens of Europe. This is the starting point, if we want to heal ourselves not only from the virus but also from our selfishness that makes us powerless.  If we have to put on masks to protect ourselves from the virus, we must drop the masks that prevent us from acknowledging our mistakes. We have seen the fragility of our health systems and the need to build more resilient systems. The Europe we want is not that of unnecessary walls but that of the trains and helicopters that we see crossing borders, taking patients to places where beds are still free. The Europe we want is the one that will find the cure for the disease and is ready to share it.  The momentum of solidarity and spontaneous cooperation must be structured into a European health mechanism that makes Europe better prepared and more sovereign for the next time. In the face of tomorrow's crises, Europe must be ready to face the next crisis in full independence. For this, we need to think now about this European health mechanism that must be in place. Second, the economy. We all used the same phrase: Whatever it takes. Now let's take action. Not a single one of our Member States is able to emerge strengthened from this crisis on its own, regardless of its power and membership or not in the Eurozone. We must not be lonely but in solidarity this time.  As I have said to the Member States and to the Commission, this is not the time to play with little arms. Let's hit hard with a massive stimulus package, as Ursula von der Leyen said, with a new Marshall Plan, with the prospect of digital and green deal. We have the strategy, we now need the ambition to put this strategy in place. It is for investment, it is for jobs, it is for small and medium-sized enterprises and for the industries of tomorrow. This crisis is putting a strain on the internal market, which must be respected and strengthened. Thirdly: no, authoritarian regimes are no better equipped than our open, democratic societies, based on freedom and respect by each of the collective rules. Fear, concealment and withdrawal are not antidotes but poisons. Under no circumstances should democratic values or our individual freedoms be called into question. And that,'s what everyone needs to hear, including Viktor Orban. We must do whatever it takes also to heal our democracy and restore the rule of law by all possible means. On all these subjects there is a question: what will Europe be after this crisis? A mammoth with feet of clay or on the contrary an agile and robust shuttle that is always where it is needed? Let us not wait for the next crisis to understand that our future as Romanians, Italians, Poles or Swedes will not be directly proportional to our individualism but it will be directly proportional to our ability to work together. This crisis demonstrates the urgency of tackling the conference project on the future of Europe, which is more relevant than ever. Let us therefore seize this opportunity to put the European house in order with courage, to build a safer, more community and more democratic world. This crisis should not be the occasion for yet another war. Let us make it an opportunity to fight against our self-sufficiency, our hypocrisies, our prejudices and renew the world in which we live from what we have learned from this crisis.

name: Marco CAMPOMENOSI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr von der Leyen, Mr Michel, thank you for being here. I hope that this will be the last meeting at which our colleagues cannot reach Brussels, because it is important, just as we are calling for the national and regional parliaments to work, for full activity to be carried out in Brussels too, because that is what our citizens are asking for. I come from Liguria, from the North-West of Italy. Lombardy is a region close to my city, everyone in my region is aware of friends, relatives, who are either in a situation of serious suffering or have disappeared.  What perhaps some people do not know and have not understood is what is the frustration of those who are facing this emergency alone, or because they are alone in living the quarantine situation, or because alone, without the comfort of their loved ones, they have found themselves facing hospitalization, loved ones and relatives who may not even be able to celebrate the funeral.  Of course, the tragedy is not just the health tragedy, it is an economic tragedy, it is a tragedy for companies, the self-employed and workers who want to go back to producing, and that is why it will be necessary to establish standard and uniform procedures, so that the production system can return safely, and above all in the safety of workers, it can soon return to being fully operational. The problem is that, if we get out of this situation quickly in part, it will be thanks to a system of rules that existed at European level and to which we must necessarily derogate, and it is very important that we understand and examine our consciences that this system of rules is what has meant that Europe in recent years has been the continent where there was the least growth in the whole world.  It was obvious that at the first exogenous cause, such as the one we are experiencing – but it could have been a war, a strong trade crisis, a speculative bubble, like the one a few years ago – it was obvious that the system would have extreme difficulties. So one mistake that you don't have to make is, after the health emergency, to restore that system of rules that failed as if nothing had happened.  Because then we are talking about a European Union that until the other day favoured relocation through trade agreements that today make us understand that we are not, we were no longer able to produce certain things. I see some presidents, even the French saying: no, we need to return to productive autonomy, not just in the health sector, we think of the agricultural sector and many others.  Research: a few days ago, the President of the European Research Council resigned, denouncing the impossibility of working in this area at European level. So much use is made of the word truth, an attempt is made to give a European perspective, analysing a point of view which, in my opinion, is almost always and only that of a communication defending the European Commission itself, because this European Commission is a victim of itself, of the communication it has given in recent years, selling itself to the citizens as a system with a budget that Of course, it may be useful, we will work on it, but it will be able to shift very few resources.  What is needed first and foremost is for states to be free to make their own policies. We have an ECB that has a system of rules that does not work, that is not that of the Federal Reserve or the Bank of England, and we will certainly pay the price for that.  Not to mention the fact that there will shortly be a very important European Council, in which the Italian President-in-Office of the Council will go without a mandate from the Italian Parliament, which is also the victim of a division and debate, that on the ESF, on the stability mechanism, which has reached a very serious level.  I'm sure Italy will make it. I am not sure that the European Union will be able to overcome this crisis. Europe and the Member States and Italy will succeed. But I don't think the European Union.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, my fellow citizens, my fellow citizens, I am speaking to you from the Brussels Chamber of the European Parliament, where, in normal times, the heart of European democracy beats, a heart that is now beating in slow motion, a sign that we are all affected by the pandemic. The days we live are fraught with gravity. Our thoughts naturally go first to the tens of thousands of victims of the virus and their loved ones, faced with unexpected death and mourning made more difficult by the very circumstances of confinement. We also want to express our deep gratitude to all those around them, day after day and at the risk of their own health, the sick and the victims. We also take to heart all those who, in the midst of the pandemic, are on the job to ensure that our societies can simply continue to live. Europe is facing the worst crisis since 1945. The shock of coronavirus reveals the flaws of our societies, bringing to light what too many policy makers, until now, did not want to see or hear. Today, some are pretending to discover that austerity is killing, while years of underfunding of our health care and elderly services are sending thousands of people to their deaths.  They seem to discover how profit-driven globalization has made our societies vulnerable. They are aware of the devastation wrought by social inequalities: millions of Europeans have turned into poverty and forced unemployment in less than a month. Many of them can no longer afford to eat enough, while food banks are seeing their demands explode or worse, have to close because of a lack of help from our governments.  With the crisis, they realize that those who, until yesterday, were considered by the statistics "at risk of poverty" have now fallen there. Whether it is educational inequalities, the digital divide, access to decent housing, quality employment or adequate social protection, the situation reveals and further accentuates all dimensions of the precariousness experienced here in Europe. Today, the invisible cannot be forgotten. That is why, beyond the immediate impact of the pandemic, I am deeply concerned about the consequences it may have in our societies. The first risk is that, once again, it is the most fragile who are paying for a crisis in which they have no responsibility. I am thinking of those who are confined to housing that is too cramped or left to their own devices without a fixed home; those whose jobs are hanging by a thread; these asylum seekers trapped in totally inhumane conditions at the EU's borders; to the people of the South, already weakened by war, dictatorship, conflict, resource depletion and climate change, who will take the pandemic head-on.  If our collective response to the pandemic mirrors what we did after the financial crisis ten years ago, inequality within and between our societies will explode, endangering their existence. Secondly, in the name of the health emergency, our democracies will find themselves permanently weakened, abused as in Poland, or even suspended sine die as in Hungary. That powers be taken over by governments at the expense of parliaments, the judiciary and the independent press. And that we see our societies moving inexorably, in the name of their security, towards a state of permanent and widespread surveillance. Third risk is that the pandemic will provide the ideal alibi for all those who have built their fortunes on the limitless exploitation of our planet to put an end to even late, even insufficiently ambitious attempts to bring our societies back into harmony with the nature of which we are a part and on which we depend. Climate change, biodiversity collapse, resource depletion are not stopped by coronavirus. Relaunching the global economic machine indiscriminately could give a fatal boost to these dynamics even more lethal for our societies than the pandemic. The fourth risk is that this crisis will deal a fatal blow to the idea of transnational democracy that is the European project. When the pandemic hit our shores, the restrictions placed by several Member States on the export of health and medical equipment to the most affected countries sent a deadly signal: that of everyone for themselves. And today, some persist in their refusal to adopt and jointly lead a collective strategy that is not not only to respond to the pandemic but above all to rebuild and then redeploy our economies.  In this regard, we are convinced that the European Union has the means, collectively, to rebuild its economy, provided, of course, that we mobilise them collectively. And if we have to go into debt, we have to borrow together to pay back together. To leave each Member State alone in the face of this challenge is to condemn the monetary union and, ultimately, the European Union.  In this regard, I want to speak directly to Wopke Hoekstra, the Dutch Minister of Finance, and his boss, Prime Minister Mark Rutte, and to all those behind them. I would first like to tell them that their country, like Germany, like Finland, like Austria and all these 'sober' states, were the first and main economic beneficiaries of European integration.  I say to them loud and clear: economic solidarity is the price to be paid for this single market and the single currency to which they are so dear. And it is truly scandalous to hear lessons from Dutch politicians in budgetary discipline, at a time when their country has been working for decades to deprive other Member States of tax revenues that are their rightful share. My fellow citizens, my fellow citizens, at this stage, the picture I have painted for you may seem rather bleak. But you know me, you know the Greens, the European regionalists, the Pirates, we are not the ones who give up when the storm rages. The worst is never sure if you solve it. For this crisis that we did not want could also open new horizons for our societies, making victims as unexpected as they are timely. The first could be this hierarchy of trades, based on their income, which places the bosses of multinationals, traders - these professional speculators - and renters, so few of whom deserve the names of investors - or football stars at the pinnacle of our companies. Today we rediscover how essential the work of those who care for us, who cultivate the land and produce our food, who allow us to move or who collect our waste, who, yesterday and tomorrow, will allow us to learn or who, through their art, make us think, vibrate, and broaden our horizons. A second victim of the pandemic is the idea that the market is the best guarantor of general well-being. The global financial crisis ten years ago had already denied this ideological assumption, but for some it has a hard life. The reality is that the defence of the public interest, starting with that of life, is, first and foremost, the responsibility of democratic institutions and the public services they organise for the benefit of all. More fundamentally, coronaviruses could deal a fatal blow to the myth that makes human beings the undisputed master of nature. It reminds us that this nature, we are part of it and we depend on it for our lives. To be savvy gardeners, we need to know the rules and follow them. Another victim of the virus could be this obsession with the "always faster, ever faster, ever greater, ever further" which leads us to press without limits the lemon of the planet and the living in all its forms, including us. Because we discover that the global scale is not always the most appropriate and above all that the excessive maximization of efficiency - measured solely on profit - is always at the expense of our resilience, i.e. our ability to suffer shocks and respond to them. In the process, could finally succumb to homo economicus, this dehumanizing perversion that reduces the human being to an ego mobilized by the mere maximization of his material interest in the short term. For we rediscover that life requires, of course, a degree of material comfort but also of time, of space, of ideas that allow us to be in relation to others and to the world.  My fellow citizens, my fellow citizens, the pandemic marks a sudden and global pause for humanity. It is up to us to seize it and choose, together, the path that our societies must take. For us, it is unthinkable and totally irresponsible to simply want to "relaunch the machine" on the course that was his before the coronavirus. However, let us not embrace simplistic solutions. For example, while the pandemic has exposed the extreme vulnerability of our societies as a result of the international division of labour produced by neoliberal globalization, self-sufficiency and withdrawal do not provide better signs of resilience. Between local and global, between efficiency and resilience, we will have to create new balances by building on the diverse wealth of our territories.  What we are called to do is to rethink the way our societies function, taking as a compass life, a dignified life for all, rather than profit. This requires collective intelligence and creativity. Beyond the immediate fight against the pandemic, it is up to us to prepare this mobilization, together with all those who, even today, are inviting new ways of living, producing, moving, exchanging, being in contact. We're ready for it. In conclusion, I want to make this clear, at the heart of the European institutions and in particular by addressing the Heads of State and Government represented here by the President of the Council, who will meet again next week: in the face of the pandemic and its consequences, it is the very raison d'être of the European Union that is at stake. If we are not able to act in a totally united way in the face of a challenge of this magnitude, which strikes us all, what is the meaning of the European Union? For us, it is clear that national selfishness will lead us to shipwreck; it is only together that we will find the way to our future.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i too would like to thank you for this opportunity, and I too hope that we will be able to return quickly to work in the parliamentary chamber of the relevant bodies. I too would like to begin with an Italian thought, in this context, to the very many tens of thousands of victims who are unfortunately, every day, coming more and more to our attention and to the situation, so dramatic, what we are experiencing, and I too would like to emphasize the excellent and commendable work of health workers, doctors, all those who, from volunteering to law enforcement, , are enabling us to tackle this dramatic pandemic. But I think it is essential, at the moment, not only to represent what we hope will happen, but also to make some reflections of clarity on what has happened, and we must say, very clearly, that Europe has arrived in an absolutely unprepared way. It has come unpreparedly about its coordinating role that it should have played, but what is more serious is that some States have shown and manifested a very serious selfish attitude, at a time when the word solidarity, which I have often heard again this morning, should have taken over and represented concrete attention to those countries that were imagined to be the only or only victims of this pandemic.  But I think that this is an issue on which we will have to think calmly, not least because of what will happen in the next few days and months, and I want to do so, because after the health tragedy, I think it is essential to make strong and, above all, rapid reflections on what Europe will have to put in place from an economic point of view in order to prevent this tragedy from also becoming an economic tragedy and which, in a devastating way, will lead to an irreversible crisis in Europe and the Member States. Member States.  In this respect, however, I have a duty, here too, to make some essential preconditions. The first is that of a bad feeling, that we continue to think as we thought a few months ago, before this pandemic, both because of the times that are characterizing the discussions, the negotiations and the postponements, but also and above all because of certain attitudes that even in the resolution we are voting on today emerge and which our group strongly denounces. Finding time and space for political exploitation and to call for the triggering of Article 7 as a procedure against the Polish and Hungarian Governments seems to us to be out of place in relation to the situation we are experiencing and the dramatic emergencies we are facing.  In this context, However, I think it is very important that we also concentrate our efforts on economic solutions. Economic solutions will have to emerge very clearly from the point of view of concreteness and effectiveness in order to provide answers to citizens, workers and our businesses, to respond to the sectors most affected, I am thinking of tourism, I am thinking of transport, I am thinking of agriculture, manufacturing, all sectors that are in a dramatic situation and that need clear measures , which have certainly seen in the European responses – I am thinking of the activation of the instruments with the EIB, I am thinking of the SURE programme – the first important initiatives, which, however, need to overcome many red tape and which certainly need to be included in a broader reflection that is that of the European budget.  I have listened to the still clear defence of some of the sticking points of the discussions of recent months. If the budget is not radically changed, it is unimaginable to think that we can still discuss what were the programmes that have been indicated in the past. The Green deal in this context should, I think, be an opportunity to review the choices that will have to be made in this direction.  At the same time, I believe that we must try to provide clear and effective answers with innovative instruments that can express a Truly United Europe. I believe that this is what the citizens of Europe really expect, and this will be the clear contribution that the Conservative Group will make to this debate and this debate.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Group of the European Unitarian Left, how, of course, cannot we share, first, the thoughts of the victims, the tribute to the carers and all those on the front line, and the call for solidarity of our Parliament in the face of the economic, health and social crisis that is hitting the peoples of Europe hard?  In the face of the storm, European states owe themselves collective and selfless assistance. As we know, joint health planning is essential to protect us all. But let us say it now, any incantation will restore wishful thinking as long as this House merely contemplates, almost tetanus, the debacle of the coordination of European governments. Our role today must go beyond that, we must first be clear about the causes of the disaster. How can we explain that, in the joint resolution before us today, there is not a single word, a single mention of the responsibility for budget cuts in our public health systems? How can we debate the health crisis without clearly acting on the grim record of austerity? 100,000 beds closed in 20 years in France, 14% of resuscitation beds disappeared in Europe in the space of 10 years. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, austerity is killing! And we here in the European Parliament should turn a blind eye? The submersion of our care services does not come out of nowhere. By 63 times between 2011 and 2018, the European Commission recommended that Member States reduce their health spending. Liberal governments did not ask for a better excuse, moreover, to justify the breakdown of our hospitals. This evidence should have been recognized in order to learn political lessons.  Today, it was our duty, therefore, to firmly mark our rejection of all the austere conditions to benefit from European funds such as the European Stability Mechanism. The result, it's terrible. As its people die, Italy does not know whether to accept this poisonous gift from the Union and I am ashamed of the embarrassed silence of this House in the face of the impossible dilemma imposed on the Italians: to sink or to give in. This taboo hides another, just as absent from our debates, that of public debts, used by liberals as a sword of Damocles that weighs on the peoples of Europe. I can't believe you haven't seen this little music, which is echoed by the employers' unions and the governments that serve them: the crisis is expensive, we will have to make efforts, we will have to work harder. Honestly, no need to listen to the song to the chorus because we already know it very well: the people will have to pay for the crisis, and especially the poorest who are already suffering it head-on.  Your tributes to all the professions on the front line will then ring false at a time when you will ask them for sacrifices. As if the decline of social rights and austerity were the only possible way, as if this debt were inexorable, insurmountable, condemning us to tighten our belts for decades to come. Rather than remain prisoners of this logic, we should remember the words of Albert Camus's illustrious prisoner: "What interests me at the moment is to escape the mechanics, to know if the inevitable can have an outcome". And we know this issue. By affirming first that the cost of the crisis must be precisely distributed, by involving large fortunes, multinationals, tax evaders, and then claiming the need to use monetary policy to avoid the use of austerity.  Why should we rule out any real debt pooling? Why prevent the European Central Bank from directly financing the states, as the Bank of England has just announced? Why refuse to mention the question of the gradual erasure of the debts of the crisis, as has already been done in the history of our continent? It is time, ladies and gentlemen, to break all these taboos. This is the only way to loosen the noose in the face of the epidemic today and facing the climate challenge tomorrow. But all these issues, and I regret it, you prefer to ignore them. This is what a strong Parliament should have defended in order to weigh in on the current debates, which it unfortunately dismisses all too often. Let us not be stunned by spectators and have, yes, the courage to overturn the old dogmas that led us to disaster.

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Mr President, firstly, I would like to thank Ms von der Leyen and Mr Michel for their presence and thank them for their service and leadership in tackling this extraordinary challenge that we are facing. It is in times of crises that we are realising how limited and narrow the scope of our institutions actually is. Both of you have addressed the issue of the future of the European Union and the future depends on how we manage this crisis. Unfortunately, the EU does not have a great track record in crisis management. Unfortunately, the 2008 financial crisis continues to have long-lasting effects and the EU has made a mess of that. The repercussions are unbelievable and devastating, especially in the periphery of the eurozone.  The migration issue was also mismanaged. Crisis management at the time of migration was a disaster, with lasting effects even today. We can only hope that the management of the coronavirus will be different.  Mr Michel, you referred to pressure from the citizens to reform our institutions, and you are quite right. In the wake of the crisis, reform of the institutions is necessary, because if no reforms are going to be made, European citizens will write the European Union off and they will turn to solutions that appear simpler, clearer and more efficient. So, if the EU can’t learn to adapt, its adversaries will be very quick to point out the problems and to capitalise on them. The post-COVID era must be built on cooperation, on the principle of solidarity – as we have heard so many times today – but also on subsidiarity, which entails dealing with issues at local level as much as possible. Certainly there are issues where the nation states are better positioned to act efficiently and effectively, but more and more of our challenges require broader cooperation, which require action at regional, continental and global level.  Full institutional reform is inevitable, and whatever we do now, it has to prepare us for the future.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: – Mr President, the last time I spoke in this room, I talked about the real heroes of this crisis, like my sister, who is an orthopaedic operation assistant and she would normally fix your knee or your hip, but she volunteered to assist in a corona ward in a hospital in Maastricht. And she has seen with her own eyes what this horrible virus does – people who die alone, relatives who don’t have access to their loved ones, and nurses and doctors trained to heal, losing their patients – sometimes all of them – on their watch. With all due respect to the Council – who has actually left this debate now – what she needs now is no theoretical, bureaucratic debate about the Single Market. Don’t get me wrong: the Single Market needs to be at the core of our economic relaunch after this crisis, as do huge investments, the SURE initiative of the European Commission, the use of our budget as a true instrument of solidarity.  Don’t get me wrong. But what she needs right now are face masks, what she needs is protective equipment, and she needs a Europe with a heart that shows her that they can deliver and that we will never, ever, become as dependent as we are now on other parts of the world when it comes to the production of our core medicines and our protective equipment. What she needs is solidarity in action, and I’m thinking about the ICU patients who have been taken from the Netherlands to Germany, for example. She doesn’t need to see the images of the Russia huggers of this continent pretending that Italy gets more support from Russia than they get from the EU. That is not true and we need to speak out about that. And, lastly, what she needs is a Europe that learns from its mistakes. There were mistakes made in the introduction of the measures against the coronavirus. One Member State doing one thing, a neighbouring country doing another thing. And the Council is going to repeat the same mistake. The Commission wanted to propose unity in an exit strategy and Member States tried to stop her. I say to the Commission: good for you that these guidelines are there. Stay strong and show my sister and all these others that Europe can learn from its mistakes. Be better and deliver.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome the measures taken so far to combat coronavirus, but we need to raise the level of ambition and produce tangible benefits for all citizens, especially for the most vulnerable groups in this crisis: the poor, women, the elderly, people with disabilities.  In these hours I have had the opportunity to work on urgent changes to the EAFD, the fund for those most in need, which will play an essential role in the coming months and which will need more resources in the next budget. International Monetary Fund estimates that the eurozone's GDP will plummet by seven and a half points. Measures such as the European Investment Bank's extraordinary plan or the Sure Fund's European integration fund to support income and protect work are therefore very important. The priority, however, remains the preparation of a comprehensive economic recovery plan. A debate has opened on the use of 410 billion ESA capital, following the proposal to create a new line of credit within it, without cross compliance. Each country will consider whether to use it, but in any case we are convinced that it is absolutely not enough. That is why I am proud that today Parliament is tabing a resolution putting recovery bonds on the table as a means of financing reconstruction through the issue of common bonds at Community level. This request cannot be ignored by the European Council on 23 April. It is not a question of general solidarity with certain countries, but of preserving for future generations the entire political and social model of the entire European Union.  We don't waste time, we don't have any more. President von der Leyen mentioned Altiero Spinelli and Ventotene today, but we must live up to that story, not just mention it, and I say this not only to President von der Leyen, but also to all the leaders of our Union. Let us not waste time, as I said, we no longer have any. The vast majority of Europeans are asking us to finally rise to the challenge. And I think they're right, let's not disappoint them.

name: Stéphane SÉJOURNÉ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to believe that the text we are going to vote on today is the most important of the mandate. What for? Because I deeply believe that this resolution emanates from our European peoples, that in this terrible crisis we have managed to find - through this text - the european general interest. This text is neither Nordic, nor Latin, nor of the East, nor of the West. It is not owned by any of our political families. It is only for carers in Bergamo, Madrid and Mulhouse that we have demanded a European health strategy. It is for cashiers, bus drivers, families that we want a sovereign Europe to produce its masks and protection tools. It is for our jobs, our SMEs, our very small businesses that we are asking the European Investment Bank for more money. It is for the democrats of this continent that we defend the rule of law in Hungary. Finally, it is for our French, Italian, Slovak and Dutch children, those who will enter the labour market in three or five years, in particular, that we protect and want to invest together. Invest together by raising debt together without pooling past debts. This is also what our people tell us. Mr President, this empty room is a bit misleading because this institution is always full of the aspirations of the European peoples.
