Here we represent a hundred political parties all over Europe, we are the European people, elected by the Europeans and we have an agreement. I do not want to prejudge what will be voted on in the coming weeks, but we have reached an agreement. So how is it today that the European Union appears so divided? The European Council is at odds with a European public opinion which agrees with the main principles of this resolution which we are going to vote on. So I have only one message, Mr President, and it is more for the members of the Council. Ladies and gentlemen, heads of state and government, you were looking for an agreement, we must not look any further, it is there and it brings together all the ambitions. It is the expression of the European people, efficiency, democracy, our values. So listen to Parliament, listen to these citizens, listen to MEPs. We have not behaved here as party leaders in negotiating this resolution, we have taken our responsibilities, so it is your turn to live up to that commitment.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Mr President, when it comes to the health crisis, unpreparedness is murderous and indecision is culpable. And when it comes to denouncing nationalism and populism, the European Union has shown, at the beginning of this crisis, unpreparedness and indecision. Washing our hands is not enough while our health systems are crucified and our economies on land. When societies are faced with crises of the magnitude of coronavirus, they actually have an alternative: myth or fantasy. The myth plunges into a collective imagination and shared principles. Fantasy, on the other hand, diverts people's attention to dreams whose European history is full of brutal awakenings. First of all, I want to have a thought for the ravages of the doctrines of the European Union and its zealous servants. In France, it is this government that presents social security budgets that are constantly declining and which, in 2020, will still require a saving of 4.2 billion euros, of which almost one billion on hospital spending. The EUR 3 billion that the European Union is proposing to the Member States will not compensate for the damage of the budgetary savings of recent years. So Austria and Denmark propose their own deconfinous strategy. Well, immediately, the Commission wants to present a unified plan, not to fight the coronavirus but to gain credibility at the expense of nations. Germany decides to close its borders at the outbreak of the crisis, so the European Commission protests to defend the free movement of Schengen rather than human lives. At a time when the recession and the financial and economic crisis are shaping up to be a major one for the labour market, the Commission is obliged to suspend all regulations as they would worsen the recession. So what is a financial architecture really worth that needs to be cut down and removed with every crisis? The European Commission takes advantage of the disarray of the peoples to continue its ideological agenda: Albania and Macedonia's accession to the European Union, the continuation of the enlargement of the Union, the pressure to increase the contribution to the European budget. Peoples will look at those who have cradled them with fantasies and draw conclusions from them. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with a localised scope will remember that they cannot benefit from privileged access to the markets in their region because of European rules. Large companies unable to adjust the workforce without social devastation will remember that the Union is the economic entity that protects and least supports our national champions. Our farmers without fixed prices and quotas curse an unbridled free trade that was sold to them as profitable. The countries that could benefit from the European Solidarity Mechanism cannot do so because they know that it is not the people who will judge its effectiveness but a Brussels administration. National diplomacy must now prevent the migratory flows that are sure to happen as a consequence of the crisis. Meanwhile, the External Action Service is proving ineffective on Libyan and Turkish soils, from where future coronavirus immigrants will come tomorrow. It is the myth of Antigone, European if any, that should guide our action. Antigone, as you know, agreed to be sentenced to death rather than obeying unconserent laws. Sophocles placed these words in his mouth: "For me, I do not recognize for a friend the one who loves only in words." Our European Commission would do well to question what happened next to Creon and its city.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, first of all, I have not heard anyone in this chamber rebuke Communist China. For keeping quiet about the fact that, like their predecessors, the Communists in the Soviet Union were silent about Chernobyl, these people wiped out the truth with which they sacrificed thousands of lives, including our fellow citizens in the European Union. Everyone in this room is supposed to be a Democrat, and no one said a word about the responsibility of communist China. Secondly, Mr Commissioner, the European Commission is late and its delay is a reason for national states to take measures and close their borders. Thirdly, dear, I asked the honourable Mr Michel, dear Charles, not to shame him that the Council he chaired decided today to adopt the Mobility Package. If you do not know, honorable colleagues, currently hundreds of thousands of Eastern drivers, including Bulgarian, Polish, Romanian, Czech, save the lives of people in Belgium, in France, in Germany, in the Netherlands. Now they are welcome, now you do not go after them, now there is no mobility package, now they work 12 hours, they sleep in the booths, you do not take them to Bulgaria, but you want, when they do the job, saving lives, to leave 200,000 people out of work. This, gentlemen and ladies, dear and honorable, is hypocrisy and is quite crazy. Dear, I read the declaration, I can safely say on behalf of the European Conservatives that we will not join. In times when you are asked for economically sensible, meaningful measures, there is talk about Poland, about Hungary, about refugees, about all things. That's not wise. I'm going to be done. Dear, if meaningful measures are not taken, you risk turning this virus into Chernobyl for the European Union.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Mr President, thank you to the European Commission, thank you to Mr Michel for the Council. As usual, we hear that the solution is more market. Yet today we are facing a colossal market failure. And I'm not just talking about shortages, the shortage of masks or respirators. I am also talking about vaccines and medicines. Velen van de 130,000 slachtoffers hadden waarschijnlijk kunnen vermeden worden, want dit is niet de eerste dodelijke corona-epidemie. We hebben SARS-1 gehad, we hebben MERS gehad. Wetenschappers stonden toen heel dicht bij de ontwikkeling van een medicijn, van een behandeling. Maar wat gebeurde er? Het geld droogde op. Het geld droogde op, in waarom? Because multinationals preferred to invest in something else, which paid off more, a skin cream, for example. And then there, the cynicism is total. Now that everyone wants a treatment, that everyone is looking for a vaccine, Big Pharma is ready to put the grapple on it, to grab this through patents, through exclusivity to sell it to people because we know that there will be money to be made. For me it is very clear, there will be no profits on this pandemic, we cannot let that happen. En daarom moeten wij vandaag de Europese geneesmiddelenwetgeving aanpassen. Die beschermt vandaag beter de octrooien, de winsten van de big pharma dan de gezondheid van de mensen, en dat kan niet langer. Daarom wil ik u vragen vandaag dwanglicenties voor te stellen op Europees vlak. Compelling licenses break patents and provide cheaper, generic medicines. Nelson Mandela used them in South Africa when multinationals refused to lower the prices of HIV drugs. Well, Nelson Mandela broke the monopoly of these big multinationals. Let's do the same today. Because the question today is: do we want to be on Nelson Mandela's side or on Big Pharma's side, on the side of life or on the profit side?

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: – Signor Presidente, onorevoli colleghi, quando ho fatto il mio ultimo intervento in questa Camera in Italiano non potevo sapere che avrei avuto presto un altro e powerful motivo per farlo di nuovo. Parlare oggi in Italiano ' un modo per esprimere solidariet' e vicinanza al paese dell'Unione europea che ' il pi' dura dura colpito da questa maledetta pandemia, ma che rappresenta il simbolo di tutti i paesi dell'Unione europea. Come l'Italia, anche la Catalogna' hard colpita dal Coronavirus. Oggi sarebbe un giorno per esprimere la nostra solidarietTM in ogni lingua dell'Unione europea, perché questa crisi sanitaria nonché economica e sociale minaccia tutti i nostri paesi. Oggi pio che mai l'Unione deve vedersi eats un'unica societo.  And today is a day to express, of course, our solidarity — mine and that of my colleagues and MEPs, Carles Puigdemont and Clara Ponsatí — with the whole of Spanish society, and our solidarity and our pain for the trace of deaths that this pandemic is leaving in it, with special intensity in Madrid and La Rioja. We need powerful new instruments to combat the two main dimensions of this crisis: health and economic crisis. At the economic level, I fully support the proposal to set up a fund financed through reconstruction bonds, issued as joint European debt, and supported by the Community budget.  At the health level, ambition to promote those health research strategies, which, among other things, allow us to drastically shorten the time currently required to find an effective vaccine to eliminate this or future pandemics. We will only achieve this with more robust public or parapublic research and greater international scientific cooperation.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, the experience of the past two months has shown that no nation alone can win against this virus. Our response, the European response, has already made a difference on the ground. We have proven that solidarity can win over selfishness and we can help European people in need. Three weeks ago we stood in this Chamber and we granted EUR 37 billion to the fight against corona. And then, in this Chamber, I asked the President of the European Commission to do more. I said that more is needed and I asked her to allocate every single euro of the EUR 4 billion in reserve – unused in the budget of the Union for 2020 – to the fight against the coronavirus. And now the Commission is proposing exactly that. It proposes allocating more than EUR 3 billion to people in need and I think we should approve this. And we should approve it quickly. It will become law and it will reach those in need – patients, doctors, hospitals. But I say more is needed. This is just the beginning and we should plan for the future. Europe should help where there is the biggest need and this is in hospitals. We see countries, we see regions, we see cities not capable of saving the lives of their citizens. People are looking at us. They are looking for solutions and I say I have a plan, I have a proposal. Let us create a European healthcare solidarity fund to invest in hospitals in need in every corner of Europe. I propose the creation of a EUR 50 billion fund which should improve the situation in hospitals in every corner of Europe and make sure that wherever people live in the European Union, they receive good healthcare. The question is, do we have the money? And my answer is of course we do. We should put the money where it is most needed – saving the lives of the citizens of Europe. My Group proposes this as an amendment today to the resolution and I am asking all groups to unite behind this objective. Let’s make this project a project of the European Parliament. Let us have the European Parliament of 2020 be remembered for creating a European healthcare fund which brings hope to the people of Europe and which saves lives.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Mr President, in the face of this crisis of highs, the Union cannot give a minimum answer. Shy political actions are no longer worth it, they are no longer worth economic dogmas. Faced with this historic challenge, Europe must act with political courage, innovation and solidarity to get out of social and economic hibernation without leaving anyone behind. Otherwise, our project, our common destiny, is in danger.  The Eurogroup agreement is certainly a first step in the right direction, but it is not enough. Europe needs a comprehensive medium- and long-term ambitious reconstruction plan, based on the idea of a new common European Marshall Investment Plan, as proposed by President Sanchez. A plan that includes instruments, funds, European reconstruction bonds in solidarity, solidarity.  Today, from this House, we must send a strong signal to all our citizens, with the adoption of a first roadmap, the Joint Resolution which will support my entire delegation and a series of budgetary and regulatory measures that respond to the health, economic and social needs of our citizens, especially those of the most vulnerable. We must always think of the general and common interest, making immediate use of all financial instruments and the provisions contained in the Treaties. And we will do so by defending democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  The recovery should be at the heart of the European Green Pact, digital transformation and other priority sectors such as tourism, fisheries and agriculture and the cultural industry. And finally, this is important, President, this House must participate fully in the development of the reconstruction plan and lead the preparation... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Mr President, COVID-19 is certainly a sign of the least good but also of the best that human nature can be. The best of human nature, of course, is the boundless commitment of our white blouses, to which we can never say thank you enough. The best of human nature is also all these outpourings of solidarity that are flourishing all over Europe. It is these entrepreneurs who change their production lines, it is these little hands, everywhere, who improvise seamstresses to sew fabric protective masks and it is often these same exemplary citizens who challenge us, and who ask us where Europe is, what is Europe doing, is Europe doing enough? So, from an economic point of view, this has already been said, yes no doubt, but it is the future that will tell us: stability pact, state aid, unprecedented "bazooka", taboos have literally broken down. Parliament this morning is calling for more and above all for Europe to launch a new loan, a solidarity bond - the Corona Bonds - intended exclusively to contain the ravages of this crisis. On the health front, however, there are many issues and we will not hide behind the limits of the treaty forever. Today, it is perfectly inaudible. What exactly has the CDC done in terms of forecasting, anticipation? We don't know. Why, given the scale of this crisis, has the Commission not activated humanitarian aid in the heart of our territory to help overcrowded hospitals in Bergamo, Madrid and Mulhouse? What has the European medical profession gone in terms of humanitarian and civil protection? We have the means. What we lack here, so far, is audacity. And I wanted to say one thing, and I would like you to let me finish because it is essential this morning, I wanted to talk about our elders, our elders who pay the heaviest price at COVID-19: one death out of three in France, one death in two in my country, Belgium. It's a tragedy. I wanted to tell you, I wanted to say this to Mrs von der Leyen, but she is no longer here, that condemning our seniors to many more months of confinement is not the right message. Whether visitors are tested, whether they are masked, I do not have the solution here, but what I do know is that our elders die as much from sadness and loneliness as from illness. And if I can conclude anything off the subject, I find that they are the great forgotten of our European policies. It is urgent to reach out to them.

name: Filip DE MAN
text: Mr President, the European Union is failing. When it becomes clear in January that a dangerous virus is raging in China, the EU will not take any action. Neither the Commission nor the Council take decisive decisions on air traffic from China. They do not provide sufficient stocks of tests and protective equipment. They leave the Schengen borders open – wide open – until 18 March. They do not ensure other trade relations with China, or the preservation of our strategic sectors. They even failed to exert enough pressure to close down these scandalous animal markets or to ask for an explanation of the questionable virus lab in Wuhan. Of course, ladies and gentlemen, the EU is at it. Year after year, hundreds of thousands of so-called asylum seekers are allowed to enter. Illegal immigrants who have to comply with little or no sanitary regulations. So there is no cordon sanitary there. In the farthest reaches of the planet, it is not the least of the epidemics that can be declared or the EU is financially in breach of its game. Meningitis in Nicaragua, cholera in Mali, TB in Afghanistan: the benefactors in Brussels throw hundreds of millions of euros at it, and that for decades.  Last week we even saw the Commission in overdrive: no less than EUR 15 billion – eur 15 billion – will be used to help the underdeveloped countries to fight COVID-19, mainly in the bottomless wells of Africa. The Commission does not seem to know that countries such as Italy, Spain, France, have serious corona problems. Or at least, some crumbs were handed out. Flanders, for example, received 6 million euros – 6 million euros.  This shows what the eurocracy actually stands for. This elite weaned of every substance plays the planet around humanitarian benefactor, but fails when Europeans are threatened by a pandemic that originated on the other side of the world. I said.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: Mr President, the idea now, of course, is primarily for the deceased and their loved ones, and certainly also for all those who go against this pandemic day in and day out in health care with unbridled commitment. This pandemic will also draw a deep economic lead. I think this is worse compared to the financial crisis, and will get worse. It is therefore also logical that governments should do all they can to create the best possible conditions for an economic recovery, while of course – and this will be delicate – the right balance must be maintained between health care considerations and, on the other hand, economic recovery, jobs and prosperity.  This is also the time to keep a close look at the major projects. We remain in favour of a sustainable transition that focuses on future-oriented innovation and competitiveness. However, these objectives must be fully fitted into a strategy of economic recovery. The Eurogroup package will certainly provide support, but the big financial bazooka will of course remain the policy of the European Central Bank, as it is now and has been drawn up.  I call for solidarity, solidarity between Member States and regions, where the resources must be where they are most needed and used in the right way.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Mr President, of course the European Union didn’t cause the virus, but the relentless pursuit of neoliberal capitalism has actually hampered our ability to deal with it and caused the damage – stripping our health services, leaving our workers exposed without sufficient protective gear, undermining and preventing the European Centre for Disease Prevention from doing its work, and so on. All of these have caused the damage, so to respond to that crisis with a temporary suspension of some of those rules, but ultimately more of the same, is frankly not going to cut it. It is pathetic. It is the opposite of solidarity. An insufficient fund of EUR 500 billion with strict conditions, where it is clear that ordinary people are going to be sitting with a bill later, is not going to wash. Actually, it will be the end of the European Union. We need radical change, we need debt neutralisation, we need zero—interest credit lines, we need the suspension of military expenditure, and so on. So can we please stop talking out of both sides of our mouth? If we’re really interested in solidarity, why haven’t we moved asylum seekers off the Greek islands? Why haven’t we dealt with Orbán? Why haven’t we spoken out against the sanctions damaging people? It’s not the Chinese who are undermining the European Union; it’s your own inaction.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Even if it could have been more quickly, we have been seeing a great deal of solidarity between the Member States in the European Union for weeks. However, I think that in some Member States, including those responsible for politics, the impression is being given that states such as China and Russia are still helping more than the European Union and our Member States. We should all point out more where solidarity is already being provided today – with doctors, with ventilators, with protective equipment and billions of dollars – and we should take the lead together and effectively counter these false news of the supposedly so great help from some states from outside.  And please, here in Parliament, we should not again be waging the old dispute: some are demanding money from other states completely unconditioned, others are rightly afraid that a troika will dictate conditions, as in the last crisis. However, if we agree on a common reconstruction plan for Europe's Member States and Europe's economy within the European budget, that is to say within the European institutions, it would be a common approach that does not overstate anyone, which does not overdo anyone, but where we could agree on a common path. This common path would therefore also make sense, so that we can ensure that national measures in one Member State do not downright undermine policy in another Member State.  Secondly, I would like us to maintain the necessary protection for our citizens as a matter of urgency, while at the same time giving back as much personal freedom as possible as quickly as possible. And an important building block could be an app, which we also call for in our resolution. And it is very important to me that we ensure that this app is developed in a coordinated way throughout Europe, that it is compatible in all Member States, that cross-border transport is then really possible. And if we decide today or tomorrow that the data should be stored as decentrally as possible, it must not lead to Google and Apple blocking, jeopardising or adopting the project or gaining access to the data, but our democratically elected Commission and our democratic Member States will certainly guarantee data protection better than these companies.

name: Pierre LARROUTUROU
text: Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, Pedro Sanchez is right and you are right when you say that a real Marshall Plan is needed if Europe does not want to fall into a crisis more serious than that of 1929. The first Marshall Plan was up to 4% of the GDP of the countries concerned, 4% of GDP for several years. Today, no country alone can finance a truly massive recovery plan, no country alone can find the necessary resources. And if they are financed by debt, the stimulus packages will be too weak and short-lived. That is why Europe is the solution, it is at European level that new resources can be found. You have to remember what Roosevelt did when he came to power. The country was devastated. Roosevelt, to create millions of jobs, decided to triple the federal budget, he tripled the federal budget in a few years. But Roosevelt is a strong man, he wants a balanced budget, and to have a balanced budget, he creates new resources. It creates a federal income tax, it creates a federal tax on the richest. Obviously, the first year, it doesn't work and Roosevelt accepts debt, he leaps for a few years. But then, because his stimulus package is quite massive, these taxes pay off and the budget is balanced. We have to do the same, we have to move very quickly on new resources. When I was a kid, the income tax was 45% in Europe. Today, it has fallen to 20%. Income tax has been halved while dividends have doubled. We must move forward on this tax, create a European income tax, fight against tax evasion, put a small tax on financial transactions. Today, some countries are blocking on new resources, because it is for MSF, a general budget. But these same countries are asking to move faster on the Green Deal. They will not block whether these new resources go to a Marshall Plan for climate and employment. So, Mrs von der Leyen, don't be afraid, Mrs von der Leyen, be Roosevelt! We need a Marshall Plan for climate and jobs.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Mr President, I wanted to give a message to the President of the Commission, Ms von der Leyen, but she’s no longer here. Why? Because I think that, rightly, she has spoken about the duties that our nurses, our medical people are fulfilling. But are we politicians fulfilling our duty? I’m not so sure about that because we have already been discussing this European master plan for many weeks in a row. My question is, what is the European Commission waiting for? Why can she not come forward with this trillion-sized European reconstruction and recovery plan? What is she waiting for? Is she waiting for the European Council? Then we may be waiting eight years, as is the case of the Banking Union, because there is still no banking union after the financial crisis. The European Council is playing ping pong. In February, the Eurogroup could not agree on that plan. They sent it to the European Council. Then in March, the European Council sent it back to the Eurogroup. Then the Eurogroup, in April, a few days ago, was not in agreement with that part of the plan and sent it back to the European Council.  My message to the European Commission is that this has to stop. You have the right of initiative. Take your responsibility and come forward with what is asked by the whole Plenary here, that is a trillion-sized European recovery and reconstruction plan, not based on mutualisation of that, not guaranteed by the Member States – they have no money anymore, they will all be in deficit – but based on new own resources. It’s an historical moment for the European Commission. We need a large type of initiative. You remember Delors. There was a big crisis, an economic stagflation crisis, and he launched the single market and it lifted us out of the crisis. The same is needed now. The European Commission has to act and not wait for the outcome of a Council that will not decide next week. (Applause)

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has Louis XVI was on the hunt when his messenger brought him news of the storm ingess to the Bastille. "This is a revolt," the king calmly said. "No, Sire: the revolution." Ludwig hunted, we debated: in January about the Green Deal, climate rescue and the future of Europe, and in February about the third gender and human rights in Madagascar. A top official in Madrid even calmly remarked – in February, mind you – that he expected only a handful of Corona-infected people.  Asylum for the world, climate emergency and gender delusion are collective symptoms of a neurotic evasion of the hardship of self-assertion and the omnipotence fantasies of an impotent patient: Europe's flight into disease.  The Corona crisis makes it clear that Europe is sick and therefore more susceptible to disease. More people are dying here than anywhere else in the world. Japan, Taiwan, South Korea, albeit close to the source of the infection, acted quickly, with border closures, masks and tests. As a way, fewer people died and the economic damage remains less. Eastern Europe also has fewer deaths, because Viktor Orban and others care about their country and not just about the world. Western Europe, on the other hand, has failed, warnings have been struck, borders closed too late, protective clothing not worried or even destroyed, and migrants and migrant workers flown in untested.  What now? Ministers are wringing their hands, not knowing what to do. There is only one thing they all know: we need more Europe. Why only? Because, like Louis XVI, we issued warnings and are making more and more debts? It is now necessary to harmonise and level the way: unemployment and deposit insurance, health policy and taxes. Why? And from now on, all debts shall be made together, each according to his needs, and everyone shall be liable according to his possibilities. And until that is the case, the ECB should print the money.  All this is madness. Harmonization does not mean optimizing, debt does not socialize, reduce it, and printing money does not mean being richer. How do you go bust? Ernest Hemingway's answer was: "In two ways: first very slowly and then very suddenly." And how do you get healthy again? Not by fleeing into the disease and like Lemminge all together over the cliff, but by ordering one's own garden, and not the common.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Mr President, in the debate on eurobonds, we have seen that the euro area has become a quarrel zone. But I don't blame Italians, Spaniards, French, Germans or Dutch. I love them all. I am actually putting the blame on the euro area, because the problem of the euro area is the euro itself, Mr Verhofstadt. A single currency does not bring unity. On the contrary, it is an illusion, an illusion, to have a currency union with so many countries at the same time. That's never been seen in history. The differences are too great and the euro makes them even bigger. And what's the consequence? Quarrels, everywhere, between countries, in countries, emotions, anger, recriminations, bitterness. Mr Verhofstadt, who passionately advocates a European tax, an EU tax: the whole thing will be split up if he so wishes. Then we find ing the steep demise of Mr Beck.  I have the feeling that we are on the divide, the north-south divide in the eurozone that can no longer be bridged. The eurozone is becoming a prison for everyone for other reasons. The Portuguese Prime Minister has suggested that the Netherlands should stop participating in European decision-making and leave the euro area. I thank the European Prime Minister for that suggestion, I will think about it. What I see is debt-to-debt debt. I see in front of me the tower of Babel, ladies and gentlemen, and you all know how that ended.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, COVID-19 has certainly shone a light on obvious inequalities. What do we do about it? President von der Leyen said ‘saying sorry only matters if we change our behaviour’. Nurses, care-workers, bus drivers, supermarket workers, are now described as ‘key workers’. Are we going to compensate them for the years of being under-valued, under-paid and now risking their lives? We can’t go back to normal, because normal wasn’t good, it was neo-liberalism. Neo-liberalism lies at the heart of the EU and at the heart of everything that’s wrong with it. The pursuit of it is why we have not agreed to allow coronabonds for the likes of Italy, Ireland and others. it is why Germany and the Netherlands slammed the door in their face – they talk the talk on solidarity but they don’t walk the walk. The Bank of England can issue their own currency and debt. Can the eurozone? Or would it not suit the more powerful countries? We want the eurozone project to survive but it has to change, it has to say goodbye to neo-liberalism. Your resolution is calling to fight the virus by calling on Russian and Chinese propaganda to stop. That’s propaganda in itself! Are there any adults in the room?

name: Andor DELI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. We are facing an unprecedented crisis in the history of the European Union. We're facing a deadly virus that won't spare anyone. This invisible enemy has prompted us to change our habits, slow down our familiar rhythms, and stay away from loved ones, even when they need us most. The central theme of today should be coordinated European action to combat the Covid-19 pandemic. However, even this tragic question does not seem to have been able to distract some Members from attacking national governments with malicious lies and spreading fake news. Such lies are the news of the suspension of the Hungarian Parliament. While the Hungarian Parliament is constantly in session and continues to work at full capacity. Not so for the European Parliament, because if we look around, we can see that more than 90% of its fellow Members cannot attend meetings or express an opinion. And the Hungarian Government is only doing what the Constitution required and what the Hungarian people expect of it. This is to protect human lives and alleviate the pressure on the economy. It does so within the framework of the legal mandate voted on by the Hungarian Government, the National Assembly and under the continued supervision of the Constitutional Court. This is not a time for ideological debate. They don't have to be on the agenda. Rather, the European Union should think and step up its efforts in a way that is quickest and most effective in helping the countries in need.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Many thanks to all those who, like Esther de Lange's sister, are fighting this pandemic in the first place, and a huge thank you to all those who are now working every day, day after day, to ensure that our basic services are secured. For one thing this crisis clearly shows us: 75 percent of them are women who work in system-maintaining jobs – 75 percent. These jobs are systemically important, but often systemically misunderstood.  And it is also women who, right now, in a society that stays at home, are increasingly exposed to domestic violence. We therefore need measures that are pragmatic, that are quick and that are now being used immediately, that protect women, but also children, from domestic violence. A large number of single mothers are at home, have a job and then have to teach their children at the same time. Here, too, we need to do much more to ensure that these very practical problems are managed in accordance with social insecurity and that we take appropriate measures here. So this crisis is female. The United Nations has stated that we run the risk that COVID—19 will make the tentative progress that has been made on gender equality disappear, that they will suddenly disappear. In other words, we must be very, very vigilant here.  After the financial crisis, we bailed out banks; we now need to save the real economy – the real economy and its employees. That is why Eurobonds are only a start once. We need real solidarity, real cohesion and the big ideas.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, apologies have been stund: that is fine. There has been talk of heroes and victims: it is obligatory. But this Parliament of all Europeans must stand today, giving answers. That's a must. Because if not, there will be no future for anyone. We're too small, too vulnerable to get ahead if we're alone.  The European Union emerged from the ashes of war. Our parents or grandparents built these institutions and this Parliament. And there are powers outside that could exploit our vulnerabilities if we unjoint ourselves, if we give in to small selfishness, to nationalism, to lying, if we hear the siren chants of the fanatics of exclusionary identity. We must demand. This Parliament must demand that every mechanism be used to help resist and overcome the health crisis and the weakness of the economies of families and businesses. We cannot spare any effort to protect citizens. First, to save lives and then to save jobs, freedoms and the project for the future, especially from the younger ones. The President of the Commission has listed measures. The Eurogroup agreement is well oriented, but it is not enough to deal with the wounds that are emerging in this crisis. That's why we need the massive economic reconstruction plan. A temporary plan, funded in part by existing instruments. But also those 'reconstruction bonds' guaranteed by the Union budget. That could be history. We can't fall short.  And it is certainly time to act in a way that allows Europe to abandon this mere lender mode of the states. We need to invest together in the future. Our parents and grandparents built these institutions without which we would be adrift today. Many of them are dying. As Europeans, we must prepare policies so that it never happens again. To be stronger and more sensible, so you don't need heroes, so you don't have to cry victims.

name: Helmut GEUKING
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the So first of all, I would like to stress that my thoughts are, of course, with the many victims. I thank the many helping hands in the individual countries.  I now come to what we are to vote on today. Unfortunately, I will vote against it, for simple reasons: I think to myself that such things as Poland – presidential elections – as in Hungary, or things like abortion, have nothing to do with it. We need an instrument here to combat the Corona crisis and nothing else. The other is far too important to us, and we can take that up at a later stage and work it out and work it out accordingly.  Incidentally, I would urge that we should not look back, but that we should look ahead – in a crisis, we must look forward. Who do you have to finance? Who do you need to strengthen? I say that we must strengthen the building blocks – the elements – of our society: these are the families that are in the shadows, and that is why we should introduce child benefit here. This is the child guarantee that Mrs von der Leyen has brought into play in order to directly strengthen purchasing power, to stimulate the money cycle, to bring the money directly to the people, that is to say to the families of Europe who desperately need it. I appeal to this and i would like to express my sincere thanks. One minute is unfortunately far too short.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are writing the pages of the history books that our grandchildren will study. In this time of decision, when the old continent seems more fragile, between solidarity and nationalism, what is our legacy? The union or the division? The bureaucratic machine or hope? Do we want a Northern or Southern Europe? A Baltic Club, a Latino association, a Federation of Slavs? No! Faced with truly global problems, shared problems such as this virus, which does not run into or stop at borders, we have refugees on our doorsteps surviving in humiliating conditions, the United States is underpusing the relationships we trust so much and, why not say, the economic threat to our businesses from the Chinese economy. How come we can't get together?  In a world where the greatest uncertainty we have is the uncertainty of the future, the best we have to offer our citizens is our own division? If, as Pope Francis reminded us, we are all in the same boat, then each one cutting a board and thinking that if he is saved is a weak illusion. Each for himself we are fragile, like a branch of brittle tree, but together we have the confidence and strength to face the future.  Europe is freedom. Europe is democracy. Europe is the best place in the world where we could live. Let us support those who need it most at this difficult time: young people, the unemployed, the elderly, those who struggle to keep their business alive. That it be industrialized and that hope be distributed. Let us not allow Europe to be another victim at the hands of this pandemic.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, there has been a tremendous anguish in the European economy, as if it had been a tsunami warning everywhere and at the same time. With economies paralysed, we know that we are seeing only the first signs of a giant wave, which will be devastating for businesses, jobs, families and the European project itself, if an immediate, strong and supportive response is not given at European level. The European Parliament gives an important signal of unity and responsibility by presenting a joint resolution today and with it addresses a clear message to the Commission and the Council and, above all, to that minority of governments which have blocked a more sympathetic response. We need a great economic recovery plan that has the necessary financial means. We therefore advocate an urgent political agreement for a multiannual financial framework, not of cuts, but of strengthened and with more own resources. We also unambiguously advocate the creation of recovery bonds, i.e. the issue of debt securities by the European Commission itself, guaranteed by the European budget, to finance investment and avert a new sovereign debt crisis. Today, this Parliament that the people have elected is, more than ever, the voice of the people who do not accept a Europe blocked by national selfishness. It's time to listen to this Parliament, it's time to listen to the people and decide to think about the people.

name: Ondřej KNOTEK
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Šefčovič for being here with us. In the beginning, let me express my strong respect for everyone who contributes to tackling this difficult situation. In the first part of my contribution, I would like to support the second coronavirus response package prepared by the Commission. It was prepared quickly and in line with the rigid Parliament committee recommendations, and as a result, it brings measures addressing the real needs of the citizens. Thank you for this excellent cooperation. In the second part, I would like to draw your attention to two great occasions related to COVID. Parts of the industry and energy sector have gone into serious existential risk. Facing the need to decrease the carbon footprint and at the same time to absorb the negative effects of the COVID crisis is a deadly mixture. Imagine, for example, regions whose economy is dependent on coal and tourism. The industrial and energy sector needs to survive and recover first, in order to be robust enough to succeed in the climate transition.  Therefore, I most strongly welcome you, and encourage you to put forward a short-term suspension of the emissions trading system, for example between the years 2020-2022. With this step you would save employment and prevent an increase of energy poverty inside the EU; you would stabilise businesses and the regions most challenged with the climate transition; you would get the situation under control and you would deserve respect for it.  Also, let me draw your attention to the European spas – a unique sector combining medicine and tourism. This sector has enormous potential to improve public health, not only in general, but also specifically after the COVID disease. The spa sector has also been in serious difficulties and deserves strong and fast support. Any Commission initiative here will be most welcome.

name: Carlo FIDANZA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we will not emerge from this crisis with crocodile tears, effective proclamations and lists of good intentions on phase two, but with the ability to adapt priorities and respond immediately, the one that was lacking in the first phase of the crisis, when it was thought that COVID-19 was just an Italian problem.  Flexibility has now been guaranteed on public accounts, State aid and the Structural Funds. The ECB, having shamefully sabotaged the Italian Stock Exchange, is doing its job. Better late than never. Then there is the package for the next Council, let us make it clear: yes to the EIB's reconstruction and financing fund, no to the ESA. We met him and we don't trust him. Let us liquidate it and return the quotas to the States to deal with the crisis.  Green deal: we will say no to new burdens and ideological bans against our companies, already tried by the crisis, and yes only to virtuous investments. Finally, we call for borders to be defended because while we close Europeans at home, it is not acceptable for NGOs to continue to dominate the Mediterranean.

name: Kris PEETERS
text: Mr President, today Europe is facing the biggest crisis since the Second World War. Every day, thousands of people die in our hospitals, residential care centers or simply at home as a result of the coronavirus. People do not understand that some Member States have not shown more solidarity and that the EU has not been able to act more forcefully.  This Parliament has the opportunity today and tomorrow to make it clear to Europeans that together we can tackle this crisis decisively. That is why it is so important that the joint resolution be adopted by the largest possible majority. We fully support the guidelines and content of this resolution. It is true that we must tackle this crisis together more than ever before and take further action in the health sector. We must indeed guide our businesses, SMEs, workers, the self-employed and our farmers through this difficult period. We must indeed resolutely go for European recovery bonds, guaranteed by the European budget, because no one is to blame for this crisis. Finally, we must indeed develop the Green Deal further, but also a new industrial policy, circular economy and environmentally and economically sustainable agriculture.  I hope that, after this debate and the discussion of the amendments, we will not only adopt this resolution, but that we will implement them as a Parliament, as the European Commission and as a Council in the interests of all Europeans and the European Union.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We must continue to remind our people that human rights are the foundation of our Community. A foundation that cannot be undermined and destroyed. This cannot be done especially when a pandemic continues and a serious economic crisis begins. People get sick, die, lose their jobs and companies, workers and health workers heroistly fight a pandemic with often very limited resources, and the governments of some countries take the opportunity to violate democracy and fundamental human rights. When Viktor Orban in Hungary restricts the rights of LGBTI people and Jarosław Kaczyński in Poland is debating how to take away women's rights, we must react decisively. I would remind you that women in Poland have already difficult access to abortion, do not have access to modern contraception, there is no modern sex education in schools.  What is happening in Hungary and Poland shows that it is high time for wider Community competences. Women's rights and LGBTI rights must become one of the European Union's priorities. We can no longer escape responsibility, because equality of men and uniform guarantees of their rights are our key values, and restricting the right to abortion will hit women who are already excluded and discriminated against, women living in the countryside, the less well-off, the unemployed. If we do not deal with these matters, the European Union will continue to be a Union of different speeds. Equality must be the right of every European and every European woman, whether she lives in Barcelona, Warsaw, Budapest or Stockholm.

name: Dragoș PÎSLARU
text: – Mr President, we are right now at a time where we are talking a lot about solidarity, but unfortunately for the principle of solidarity, we need to prove that it is more than just a rhetorical exercise. That is in this period of Easter, about really taking care of one another. We have solidarity in our small communities back home. We need solidarity between different parts of our countries, we need solidarity between the states of the European Union. And this exercise related to solidarity is part of the fibre of the European Union. It’s about the values that define us now. The crisis affects all of us, but not all of us have equal chances and tools to respond to the social and economic challenges generated by it. I’m saying this because 22% of the population of the European Union is at risk of poverty and social exclusion, including 25% – one in four – of children in the European Union. This current crisis may affect people throughout Europe, but it is actually affecting people that are often invisible in our society. Social distancing is not an option in overcrowded housing and poor neighbourhoods, and the loss of jobs can only further exacerbate poverty. Discrimination in terms of access to information and to basic services exposes these people to even greater risk of social exclusion and disease. Renew Europe militates for solidarity and also for the use of existing resources and mechanisms at European level to tackle this outbreak. We will vote in Parliament the amendments proposed by the European Commissioner to regulation 223 on the fund for European aid to the most deprived. The proposed changes would bring flexibility to the instrument, additional funding – applying the 100% co-financing rate and will cut red tape – all these measures are part of the timely response, and we need to communicate that to the European citizens.

name: Robert ROOS
text: Mr President, the corona crisis is killing many people and wrecking the economy in the European Union. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) is an EU agency that aims to strengthen Europe's defences against infectious diseases. As early as 26 January, the ECDC issued the following stern warning: the potential impact of COVID-19 outbreaks is significant, the further global spread is likely, and the impact of late detection of the virus in an EU country without the application of appropriate prevention will be large, and the risk even very high. The ECDC has contacts with European Commission staff on a multi-level basis and on a daily basis. However, it has gone horribly wrong in prevention: no immediate closure of affected areas, no detection of sick incoming travellers, and appropriate measures have not been taken despite all the warnings. The consequences are disastrous. I call on the Commissioner Stella Kyriakides responsible to answer for this failed policy. If she cannot do so, she should resign immediately.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, COVID-19 is a human, social and economic disaster of unprecedented magnitude for many of us. Beyond the suffering caused by the virus worldwide, the IMF is predicting the biggest economic crisis since the Great Depression. The WTO even forecasts a collapse in merchandise trade this year in the range of 13-32%. UN agencies warn of possible food shortages. Governments around the world have implemented trade-restrictive measures that threaten to disrupt international value chains. Some of these measures were needed in the short term to ensure that medicines and protective equipment would go to those who needed them most, not those who offered the most. But in the long run, it would be absurd to arm ourselves with protectionist measures to combat this virus or any other future epidemic. If we want to get the global economy out of intensive care as soon as possible, trade is clearly part of the cure. If we allow the pandemic to quarantine trade, we are depriving entire countries, their peoples and their economies of one of the greatest drivers of development, when they need it most. The resilience of global trade rules, strategic stocks and the diversification of supply chains should be the watchwords. It is in the genetic code of the European Union that multilateral solutions for cooperation are defended. The WTO agreement on the elimination of tariffs in the pharmaceutical sector must therefore be expanded to include even more countries and even more products. Only by working together can we really bounce back and defeat this virus.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, if this pandemic is catastrophic for the direct victims of the virus, it is and will also be catastrophic for European citizens, and in particular for the most vulnerable. As Mrs von der Leyen has said, a considerable effort has already been made by Europe, thanks to its initiative but also to our support. But, as she said, more will have to be done. I would add that we will have to do something else. To do more with a more ambitious budget, to do more also with a mutualisation of the debt, necessary to cope with the economic shock and the social shock. But the key word, as everyone said today, was the word of solidarity. And I will oppose the word solidarity to austerity. As we know, the most beautiful tool solidarity is our social security system. It is our public services but also the social consultation for the determination of wages that work for redistribution. All this has been undermined by austerity in recent years. So we'll have to change that. European solidarity will also be expressed through European taxation, fairer taxation. We will have to put an end to this tax competition which has drained the national coffers and the European coffers. We must also establish extra-European solidarity because, while the pandemic is catastrophic for our citizens, it is also catastrophic for other continents and it will be dramatic for Africa. If the idea of aid and debt cancellation is to be supported, we will have to go further, again, and work to avoid tax evasion, it is also our duty to do so.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, this virus knows no borders, but it does know heroes: our doctors, nurses, paramedics, pharmacists, scientists, cleaners, delivery drivers, shelf stackers. These are the global face of resilience in the toughest of circumstances. Now, in the words of President Steinmeier, ‘this is not a war, this is a test of our humanity and of our spirit’. This pandemic should not expose Europe’s weaknesses, but it should shine a light on our strengths. Member States were slower than they should have been, but the face of Europe did show in the patients from Bergamo being hospitalised in Bavaria, Romanian doctors heading to Italy, equipment from Lithuania to Spain, Maltese and Italian designers now sewing surgical masks. Joint procurement meant even the smallest Member States could still get needed equipment. We must now extend that to the joint procurement of the vaccine, when this becomes available. European economic packages mean millions of jobs will be saved, but there are still far too many people who slip through the cracks and who find nowhere to turn. We must address them too, be flexible and continue to adapt. And finally, tied to the Covid-19 pandemic is a looming humanitarian crisis in the Mediterranean. We are seeing an increased number of boats fleeing Libya only to remain stuck at sea, unable to disembark. A coherent European approach is urgent. Meaningful solidarity is crucial. Lives must be saved, and we cannot leave front-line Member States like Italy, Greece and Malta alone. These are the crises in which Europe must show its true nature, and we cannot come up short, because we are all in this together and the only way out of it is together.

name: Sándor RÓNAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. A year earlier, I said that a United States of Europe must be created, because Europe and the world face global challenges that we can only address together and in a unified way. Such a tragedy had to happen in order to see that the global crisis does not stop at the border, it affects everyone. We therefore need common solutions and joint crisis management. The epidemic has shown the areas in which more concentrated cooperation needs to be established so that we can help the citizens of the European Union as quickly and efficiently as possible, but it has also become clear what solidarity the Member States are capable of and the enormous resources that the European Union can use to mitigate health and economic damage. Unfortunately, it has also become apparent how some Member States are aving their full power, how they refer to the emergency. For example, Viktor Orban in Hungary, under the Empowerment Act you know, makes decisions that simply have nothing to do with the emergency and the coronavirus. He denies that THERE are EU funds to remedy the crisis while leaving hundreds of thousands of Hungarian workers on the side of the road. All the lessons of the virus show us that we need a stronger, more united Europe capable of protecting its citizens from natural, health and economic damage. But it is able to protect its member states even from its European enemies.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: Mr President! When the lungs are attacked by an aggressive virus in a body where the heart is not big enough or strong enough, the human being dies. Then a child loses his parents and a girlfriend his beloved. We learn from covid-19, but we also learn a lot more.  We learn that we can compare Europe's many companies with lungs. After all, we are already talking about them as the backbone – for millions of jobs and the economic opportunities of the European Union. But now in the corona crisis, they are also our lungs. Just as we sometimes compare the climate with the lungs that are supposed to provide our children and grandchildren with a planet we may be familiar with giving them.  These lungs, Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises and the climate, need a strong heart, a heart that keeps production and innovation going in the workplace and puts bread on the table for millions of families, a heart that keeps the exchange of goods going between businesses and their customers, a heart that provides the economy to research and develop it. We need to buy the mouthbands we're missing. The EU needs a heart that can lead to the necessary green transition, so that, regardless of the 2020 corona crisis, there will be a carbon-neutral EU by 2050.  The heart I am describing is, of course, the internal market. We created it as a consequence of never going to go to war with each other again. It is therefore essential that we protect the single market, our common heart, which must beat – even through the corona crisis – regularly, tirelessly and completely free from barriers. Only in this way can we realise and disseminate, in particular, the climate initiatives and climate solutions that the planet needs and which the rest of the world, even after the acute phase of the corona crisis has been overcome, will look to the European Union to learn from and, above all, buy from. I ask that, through the corona crisis, we take very good care of the single heart of the European Union, our internal market.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, nothing will be the same as before. This is in the consciousness of each of us, of all of us. Nothing will be the same as before and will apply to everyone in every corner of the world. So here and now is the time to ask whether Europe too, even if this great dream born of the rubble of the Second World War, will be the same. We are talking about solidarity today, ladies and gentlemen. Solidarity will be the sign of the new Europe. I have no doubt that this will be the big news. But we must be careful, let us not talk about the solidarity of the strongest towards the weakest. Let's not talk about this, in the near future, no one will be strong enough to be able to do it alone. So let us talk about the solidarity that must unite everyone, all our institutions, all the Member States in order to overcome a crisis that threatens to overwhelm all our economies, all our freedoms, all our social rights, that is what we are talking about.  And then we need courage, we need every possible instrument, every new, new instrument that courage and urgency suggest. We need this and if we do not have the courage to do so, at least, i have to say that, Mr President, then really nothing will be the same as before and we cannot allow it.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a great deal has already been said. That is why I would perhaps like to begin with what my colleague Pina Picierno just said at the beginning: nothing will be the same as it used to be – that is certainly true after this Corona crisis. That is why the debates in the Member States and the debate in this House should change somewhat. We should focus more on solutions and not just talking about old, existing problems.  That is why it is right that the resolution today focuses on two essential points: firstly, the point of solidarity between the Member States and, secondly, how we can get out of this crisis together.  I would like to highlight two examples: one is that the President of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, said at the outset that it is very important to her that we restore the internal market. However, the internal market cannot be restored by the fact that the Commission has been standing down in recent weeks and saying at every opportunity that the Member States should do everything because they have been given more flexibility in state aid law and, wherever a problem arises in the economy, that responsibility is passed on to the Member States.  We have seen it very carefully in the area of tourism, in the case of the Package Travel Directive, where the Commission says that this is a task for the Member States. However, this means that each Member State may choose a special solution through state aid law, which in the end does not provide the consumer with the uniformity in the internal market that he may have wanted when he booked a trip in the neighbouring country. That is why, if the Commission wants to keep the internal market together, it must also carry out its tasks here. We have shown it impressively in the medical devices directive.  And I believe that we also need a joint start from the crisis, and this will only succeed if we also create the opening together and share the data together from those who may be infected.

name: Elena YONCHEVA
text: – Mr President, we welcome the efforts of the Commission to provide a coordinated answer to the pandemic, but the crisis demands that we do much more and go even further. We need solid European leadership. We need to see concrete proposals from the Commission to rebuild our society and our economy. I want to draw your attention to matters concerning Schengen, the rule of law and freedom of expression. On borders, we felt again that the protection of borders has become bigger than the protection of European citizens and their rights. Closing down the borders without a coordinated strategy has not and cannot solve any problems. The rule of law: this crisis should not take away our fundamental rights. People should not have to choose between healthcare and human rights, and my call is addressed not only to the Commission but to the Council as well. Break the silence in the Council on the rule of law. Identify the problems and let’s fix them together.  Also, we cannot allow Member States to silence freedom of expression. In some European countries people have been prosecuted because of expressing their opinions publicly, like in Bulgaria. And not only there. Europe must act now, as Member States we should survive this crisis together in order to save Europe.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, Commissioner Šefčovič, ladies and gentlemen, in this crisis there are two issues that can emerge as historical catalysts: the first is the way in which Europe deals with the economic consequences of the crisis. The Marshall Plan, to which President von der Leyen referred today, must take shape immediately. What does the Commission expect to go ahead and force the Member States to take the decision? The recovery bond, which we are currently voting on and proposing, needs to be combined with all available tools that will enable our economies to become more liquid. Only by overcoming fears and stereotypes, only by strengthening the presence of the European Union can we stand by the citizens at this darkest hour. And in this darkest hour, countries like my country, Greece, have shown that they have succeeded with discipline and strong government guidance from Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis. But now we need European support, European support that is not reminiscent of a memorandum, that does not refer to a troika and that shows true solidarity.  The second challenge is the new development model, which we can move on after the crisis. This is based on the Roadmap of the Green Agreement, which will provide for sustainable development, focusing on renewable energy sources, the circular economy and digital transformation. Ladies and gentlemen, the eyes of the citizens of Europe are on this. Today, the Orthodox experience Calvary, the day of the Passions. It is our duty to lead our societies and economies to the reshuffle they need, taking lessons from this global crisis.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, we are living through an unprecedented health crisis in this generation. A crisis that will have devastating economic and social consequences. A crisis that has put us against the ropes, but it has also put us in front of the mirror. And many Europeans didn't like what we've seen of ourselves at all.  After some some embarrassing discussions we have managed to get the Eurogroup to take the first step. The European Parliament, in an agreed resolution, is now calling for a comprehensive and ambitious package from the Council meeting next week. With an unequivocal message: Europe is not only playing its future, but probably also its survival, in managing this crisis. And they depend, their survival and their future, on our ability to put in place a real recovery plan for this continent's economy. A recovery plan obviously with common debt, because we want a common future, which is how the future is built. A green, inclusive, sustainable recovery plan for a sustainable economy.  As always, the greatest enemy is ourselves. The greatest enemy is the national selfishness and arrogance we see in some Member States in the Council, which always ends up causing us all to act too late and too little. Many Europeans wonder: if not now, when? to act with unity, solidarity and ambition. Now that the world economy is collapsing, that Europeans are confined and there are tens of thousands dead on the table, it is time to act with ambition for one of Europe's biggest challenges.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Mr President, defeating a pandemic such as COVID-19 is above all about controlling the disease, avoiding early death, protecting the sick and their loved ones from pain. In this case, it also requires exceptional societal measures, necessarily liberticidal. Declaring a temporary state of emergency is a powerful instrument that allows for the necessary flexibility. However, we must ensure that the rule of law and fundamental rights remain protected. That is why the Commission must closely monitor the exceptional measures taken by the governments of the Member States and intervene if there is a clear risk of drift. Parliaments must be able to continue to exercise their functions of control and legislator. At the international level, this crisis is cruelly putting us in the face of our dependence on the supply of essential goods. We must ensure that, in the future, Europe is self-sufficient in basic necessities. Here, it is medicine and medical equipment, but this must also be the case for food and other items. For what leeway does the European Union have, for example in relation to China, when it depends on its shipments of masks? Our criticism of the cover-up at the beginning of the virus or China's opposition to Taiwan's presence at WHO remains too low-key. We must protect Europe, not by closing in on ourselves but by creating the conditions to be strong at home, protect our infrastructure and our industries, and on the international stage, so that we can follow our convictions, let us show solidarity with the most exposed and vulnerable populations around the world.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, when he has political will, answers and flexibility are also found. This unfortunate situation should inspire us to act more efficiently and in solidarity even when the pandemic has passed. For example, the Multiannual Financial Framework, as arguments now look irrelevant whether Member States will invest 1%, 1.17% or 1.3% of GDP in the common budget. A common European exit from the crisis, the largest since the great recession of the 1930s, calls for much higher amounts. I support the decision to convert the remaining cohesion funds to mitigate the consequences of the pandemic while raising the co-financing rate to 100% in the coming year. Cohesion funds should be cut among the last in the next budget. I welcome the proposal to use €3 billion to acquire medical devices, protective equipment and support medical workers. I call on the Commission and the Member States to keep an eye on unverified ads across social networks and portals. Masks and disinfectants of dubious quality are offered at inappropriately high prices.  It is a good suggestion that we redirect the unsuseed funds of the Fisheries Fund to help fishermen. I propose the same for funds for agriculture and rural development. Small agricultural producers and winemakers are already suffering unbearable damage. Let me remind you that we are still waiting for adequate measures to mitigate the damage in the tourism sector. The consequences of the pandemic will be remedied with apparently huge sums of public money. These funds require fully transparent spending with serious controls on investment and money, at European and national levels. In conclusion, I support the political agreement of the four largest groups in jointly adopting the resolution. It could of course cover more elements, but at the moment political unity is more important to adopt measures for the benefit of our citizens.

name: David CASA
text: – Mr President, we are facing a common enemy, an enemy that causes harm no matter who people are and where they come from. Europe is shaped in times of crisis. It is at times like these that we best understand the importance of coordinated and decisive EU action. I welcome the progress that is being made to save lives but also to secure livelihoods. The social crisis this pandemic will leave behind could cause more damage than the virus itself. The SURE programme will be crucial to safeguard job retention across the European Union, and national governments must move forward on this proposal. But we must go even further. We must do even more to support SMEs, the backbone of our economies. They must be given access to support quickly now and in the next financial period. And we must do more, of course, to strengthen the capacity of our healthcare systems. The MMF and in particular the ESF+, for which I am responsible, will be an important tool in this regard. We must make sure that funding continues to flow, and while we will do everything possible to make sure that the new fund will be operational next year, the Commission must prepare contingency measures to ensure that funds will continue to reach those in need. Mr President, our citizens are depending on us to rise to the occasion. We must not let them down.

name: Lena DÜPONT
text: – Dear Commissioner, a Union that strives for more still holds true, and it is even more needed than ever before. We all face times of insecurity and anxiety, where there is no screenplay to rely on. This can be scary. This is already painful with the virus causing tremendous harm to our citizens. We’re too close to each other to not feel the pain of our fellow European citizens and our neighbours who are the most hit in Europe. As we ask a lot from our citizens – staying home, distancing from each other, facing the crisis on their own – let their efforts be our guidance and our guiding line. As we are all working constantly on ways to soften the consequences of the crisis, the EPP Group stands ready to discuss, to negotiate and to deliver. Count on us in your fight against the virus, in your fight for European answers. We are in this together. We could strive for more and, as it is Parliament’s slogan – we will get through this better together.

name: Lena DÜPONT
text: Vice-President of the Commission. –  Mr President, when I was here the last time we paid tribute to the heroes of today, to all of them, from doctors, nurses, to shop assistants, police and volunteers helping the elderly and the most vulnerable. Today, as Ms Düpont has rightly pointed out, we have to express our appreciation to our citizens, who are demonstrating enormous resolve and responsibility in respecting the rules for staying at home, respecting social distancing, which is sometimes very difficult, studying with their children or working from home. And I think that today, also, this debate has clearly demonstrated that Europe is rising to the challenge. We heard many examples of how the people and the Member States are helping each other, how we learn how to deal with this crisis and how we are preparing for the economic aftershocks, which for sure will come.  And for that I really would like to thank all of you: you honourable Members of this Parliament, for your energy, for your patience and also for expressing what the citizens that you represent feel in your Member States. The COVID-19 crisis is described by some as a dramatic accelerator – an accelerator for the good in us, and we have seen that in the civic responsibility and the heroism of many people who just make our society function despite this dramatic crisis. We have seen how our decision-making became faster, and I agree with Mr Mureșan, who said that really, in four or five weeks we did more to tackle the economic aftershocks of this crisis than we did in four years in the previous financial crisis. But to be honest, COVID-19 has also accelerated this negativism of fake news: dangerous populism, which is testing our democracy, our rule of law. And to all of you who are concerned with this as it was expressed by honourable Member Lamberts, I would just like to assure you that we in the European Commission remain very vigilant as to what is happening in all our Member States, and we are in intensive contact with Hungary, with Poland, and we are analysing all the fake news and all the negativism which is spread on social media and we are telling them to stop it, to minimise it, and they are cooperating with us. Therefore, all of you – and I think it was very well expressed by Mr González Pons and Ms García Pérez and Mr Cioloș, that the future of Europe is decided now, and that what we need is a Europe which would be different, which would be more patriotic, more democratic, and stronger. And therefore, I would say to all of you who expressed very clear opinions on how much we need the development of massive economic investment, today I hope that you would support the package, which is aimed at immediate aid measures. But we all know that we need to invest massively in recovery, in saving our jobs, in protecting our economy from very often hostile and unfair actions. We need a Marshall Plan for the future of Europe, which will be more solid, which will be sustainable, clean, digital and, as many of you said, more resilient. Only in that way can we develop our future European destiny. We just simply have to bounce forward and we have to use the potential, the Single Market. We have to take maximum benefit and advantage from the twin green and digital revolutions, and we also have to learn the lessons of this crisis in building a more resilient and stronger Europe. In the past, as you would remember, we had to deal with different dependencies as well. The lessons learned from these dependencies was that we have to be strategic and decide which supplies we have to have simply here at home. Therefore, we are opening special storage facilities where we are stockpiling the most important medical equipment and medicines. But we also have to look at how to diversify globally and not be simply dependent on one single country or company. And we also have to decide, after good reflection and good analyses, what we need to produce here in Europe, just to be sure that when we would need it most, we will simply have it. Therefore, I think that all of you who said that we need a more ambitious, more strategic, and more united approach should be applauded. And we need also to have the means to finance this effort. We need a strong MFF, but we need it also in a different shape – simply this time if we need the multi-annual budget, which we can front-load, which we can use almost immediately. So we can focus on the areas where the help is needed immediately – where we can make sure that we would prevent future crises and that we would be bouncing forward into the new economy, that we would fight for high quality jobs, as was mentioned by many of you, by Mr Botenga and Mr de Lange. And here I will be very open, honourable Members of the European Parliament: we would very much rely on your support to get an ambitious, modern, front-loaded Multiannual Financial Perspective, which would help us to overcome the crisis, modernise Europe, and really deal with the economic aftershocks, which we are all expecting from this crisis. Several of you raised the issue of protective equipment, masks. I want to reassure you that we are working 24/7 – my colleagues Janez Lenarčič, Stella Kyriakides and Thierry Breton are working very hard to make sure that we would very soon see the good results of the joint procurement, which would make sure that our doctors, our nurses and our citizens have all they need for their work. I also would like to applaud European industries, where more and more companies are converting their usual production to produce masks, disinfectant gels, or simply started the production of ventilators, which are so much in need in our hospitals. I believe that in a couple of months, with the strong power of the European industry, we will show what I believe will be very impressive results. Ms Ries raised the issue of the elderly and the most vulnerable. My mother and my mother-in-law in Slovakia are in a similar situation. Therefore, we adapted the funds for European aid for the most deprived and most vulnerable. Let’s have a look together and see if the adaptation is far-reaching enough – what can we do more to make sure that we would help also those who need it most? To conclude, I would just quickly react to two very important remarks. One by Mr Caspary, who was raising the issue of the virus-tracing app. Here I would like to reassure all of you that what we are talking about will be a European app on which the best expertise that Europe can offer is used; that it will be tracing the virus and not tracking people; that it will fully respect protection of personal data. It would be voluntary for the people who would like to use it.
