It will be anonymous, and in practice it should work in a way that it would inform you by text message that you might have been exposed to the virus and you should take the necessary precautions. Mr Verhofstadt, Ms Spyraki, Mr Larrouturou, Mr Silva Perreira, raised, very forcefully, the issue of the MFF recovery plan, and I would add also what we are working on: adapting the Commission work programme, which we want to present to you before the end of the month. I think that all the measures altogether, as our President, Ursula von der Leyen, highlighted, made it possible that within a short period of time we mobilised more than EUR 3 trillion coming from the Member States and from the European budget. I agree with you, we need more, and I believe that with your support we can get a good multiannual financial perspective. But we also know that to get there, a lot of diplomacy is required, because the decision on MFF is unanimous, and therefore we are working extensively, especially our President, talking to the leaders, making sure that the proposal we put on the table would be ambitious enough but at the same time will be supported by all EU Member States, because this is what we need at this point in time. We want to learn from the past. We want to use leverage. We want to use the best of our policies, which deliver good services and progress to our Member States. And I believe that all these would be properly reflected in our next proposals. To conclude, I just really would like to thank all of you for your ideas, for your suggestions and the support you demonstrated today, during all these very difficult weeks, and I believe that with your support we will build the new Europe, which will emerge from this dramatic crisis.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner. President Michel asked me to apologise because he had to leave earlier. His staff have followed the debate closely and will forward the opinions of Members as soon as possible. In accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure, seven motions for resolutions have been tabled. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " The spread of COVID-19 around the world and in Europe is a huge challenge that we face today. I therefore fully support the mobilisation at European Union level of additional funding for healthcare facing a pandemic. This will allow the European Commission to purchase and hand over medical equipment such as masks and respirators to all countries. The transport of patients and the construction of mobile field hospitals will also be financed. This is an unprecedented act of European solidarity, the beginning of a new opening of integration. All reasonable understood that only together and only strongly cooperating, we would be able to deal with such disasters. And there will be more and more of them, because the pandemic has not stopped the climate catastrophe.  Recent events have highlighted the importance of joint European action. That is why, in the European Parliament resolution, we call for extremely broad action by all the EU institutions to combat the virus, but also to rebuild and modernise the European economy quickly and powerfully. At the same time, however, we must not turned a blind eye to the actions of authoritarian governments, which in some EU Member States are using the pandemic to restrict citizens' rights and increase the privileges of power. Europe will sooner or later emerge stronger and even more integrated from the pandemic. Poland must remain part of a democratic European Union.

name: Atidzhe ALIEVA-VELI
text: in writing. – The COVID-19 pandemic does not recognise limits. In recent weeks, the EC and all Member States have been able to demonstrate that well-coordinated policies at EU level and good cooperation between Member States are at the heart of the pandemic, and should also underpin the development of a strategy to address its economic and social consequences. I strongly welcome the actions taken so far by the EC and the Member States and believe that together we can achieve even more.  Unfortunately, the health sector is still experiencing a shortage of vital equipment, protective clothing and consumables, which means that the EU and all Member States must continue to work together to strengthen national health systems. A huge number of SMEs, hundreds of thousands of self-employed people and huge numbers of workers are put in a situation of uncertainty and we need to mobilise all available instruments so that we can limit job losses and help provide the liquidity needed for SMEs. Special measures should target the most vulnerable and deprived people and the sectors most affected, such as agriculture, transport and tourism.

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: Writing. – COVID-19 is much more than a medical crisis: it is a social crisis with devastating effects on our infrastructure. Let us take the situation in schools: they are closed at the moment – how long, nobody knows. Initial considerations, e.B. in Lower Saxony, are to keep the schools closed for the time being until the summer holidays.  I therefore call in a resolution for measures to be taken to ensure the education of our children even if, as in the present situation, regular education is not possible for a long time. Where is crisis management? Where are the crisis meetings? There is no such! So, while Krethi and Plethi are once again being showered with taxpayers' money, there is no plan for how to educate our own children in this crisis. And I can no longer hear the ever-trying commandment of charity: the commandment of charity is primarily for our neighbour, and not for the over- and the next. What is more, the commandment of charity is led ad absurdum and is almost reversed when the overandandororandorisism is helped, at the expense of our neighbours!

name: Marc ANGEL
text: in writing. – I deem it important that we act against any attacks on LGBTI rights or women’s rights, also when these attacks are covered by measures given to Covid-19 pandemic. Access to legal abortion and sexual education must be maintained, also during a sanitary crisis! We, Socialists have a clear line on fighting for LGBTI rights and women’s rights, which we will not drop just because we are currently undergoing an exceptional sanitary crisis. In this sense, I strongly condemn the attempts by the Hungarian Government to backtrack on trans- and intersex persons’ rights and the attempts of the Polish Government to further criminalise abortion care, stigmatise HIV positive people and undermine young people’s access to sexual education! I also underline that Member States must always follow EU rules and therefore internal border controls must be based on the existing legal provisions and must remain exceptional, limited in time, justified, proportionate and transparent. As part of a crisis exit strategy, the restrictions must be lifted as soon as possible. However, at the meantime, cross border travel, in particular in healthcare and elderly care, as well as in the agri-food sector, must not be limited. These concerns must be mentioned in our resolution.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Writing. – The corona epidemic has hit all countries hard. Human suffering has been greatest in Belgium, Spain, Italy and Luxembourg. We do not know the extent of the economic losses, but they are expected to be severe in all Member States. Even in conditions where all Member States are in trouble, solidarity between Member States remains important.  I consider it necessary to issue common Eurobonds. They would strengthen the position of the euro as a reserve currency. Globally, 62% of all reserves are in the US dollar and only 21% in the euro. The position of the euro as a reserve currency would be significantly strengthened if we were able to agree on joint Eurobonds. This would benefit both the countries that have followed conservative fiscal policies and those countries with high government debt.  Discussions about the possibility of issuing common Eurobonds began even before the euro was born. Unfortunately, joint Eurobonds have not been agreed. As long as there is a moral risk that countries with more conservative fiscal policies will have to pay higher interest rates on common bonds, there will be no common Eurobonds. It is not appropriate to focus on the question of whether eurobonds are for or against eurobonds. We should strive to create common bonds that benefit the euro zone as a whole.

name: Pablo ARIAS ECHEVERRÍA
text: in writing. – The joint motion for a resolution on the Union's coordinated action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences is an initiative jointly presented by six groups of the European Parliament, including the PPE Group. It addresses the measures taken so far by the European Commission and proposes new ones, including ways of reforming the functioning of the Union. From my group, the EPP, we supported this joint resolution proposal, as it is time to join forces. The European institutions must live up to the circumstances and deal with the pandemic on the basis of the principles of solidarity and responsibility. With this joint motion for a resolution, we call on the Commission to manage the health and social crisis, but also to remember that we must prepare for the recovery of our economy. We must do everything we can to keep our businesses afloat, especially SMEs, to protect employment and our consumers. The single market is a key tool; economic and social recovery will be accelerated if we keep internal borders open.  We therefore call on the European Commission to act in coordination with the Member States to ensure that the European Union is strengthened from this crisis.

name: Anna-Michelle ASIMAKOPOULOU
text: Writing. – I've always been proud to be Greek. Today even more so. Because Greece, thanks to the quick reflexes and determination of its prime minister, Kyriakos Mitsotakis, but also the effectiveness of the Greek government, treats the COVID-19 pandemic in an exemplary way. The Prime Minister has made responsibility for human life a top priority. The Greek people took on their own responsibilities, heroically, on the front line of the battle and in every house. Despite the long-standing crisis, Greece is implementing an ambitious programme to deal with the consequences of the corovirus in terms of solidarity and justice. It makes strides in digital transformation and in strengthening the health system. Always with respect for democracy and its institutional functions.  The pandemic does not discriminate, it knows no borders and nationalities. In order to defeat the common enemy, all Member States must assume their responsibilities. In terms of solidarity we share the burdens, not of the past, but of what emerges for all of us, to recover. Europe is on an existential trail. It must now do 'whatever it takes' in terms of responsibility, solidarity and democracy. Greece is on its way to Europe. And I will always be proud to be Greek and I want to remain proud to be European.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: in writing. – Unfortunately, facing the COVID-19 pandemic showed that the European Commission has not reacted in due time: the measures adopted were not sufficient and its coordination role was lacking. Now more than ever we need strong, adequate and timely measures to protect our citizens, our economies including the most impacted sectors, and also the Single Common Market. I welcome the emergency funds and the exceptional measures that allow more flexibility in the use of EU cohesion and structural funding to alleviate the effects of the coronavirus. Nevertheless, I am also calling for a more coordinated European action to protect EU citizens and support the economy during and especially after this unprecedented crisis. As many of my colleagues, I call the Commission for a common recovery plan within a new, ambitious and long-term budget to mitigate the socio-economic and financial effects of the lockdown. This would prove essential in order to maintain EU’s credibility, solidarity and unity among its Member States. This crisis affects everyone and this is crucial that all necessary measures are timely debated and adopted.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. While the health crisis should have been an opportunity to present concrete proof of European solidarity in action, it is clear that generosity has been exercised towards the whole world, before our own. Just on 22 April, the Commission unveiled a series of exceptional aid to the UNION's 'neighbourhood'- a concept that includes the Balkan states as well as Tunisia and Jordan - amounting to THREE billion euros. Worse, despite some commendable actions, such as Germany's acceptance of French patients, the crisis will have highlighted the continuing tensions between the Member States, to the point that even the President of the European Commission had to explain herself.  Further on, this tragedy reveals the flaws in the European economic development model, which the political movement I represent has long denounced. Namely, the abandonment of all industrial sovereignty, in this case with regard to the production of medicines and medical equipment. At a time when some voices are rising in the United States calling for the repatriation of these vital productions, how many human tragedies will it take for the Union to make its aggiornamento?

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – The COVID-19 virus, which has spread throughout the world and europe, has already tragically killed many thousands of people in Europe and the world, caused irreparable damage and isolated over a billion people in their homes. This crisis has shown that the European Union and its Member States were unfortunately not enough to concentrate solidarity and coordinate their response to this pandemic jointly. The ongoing pandemic and isolation have particularly affected the most vulnerable groups in society, including the elderly, people with disabilities, those who are already suffering from poor health, and people facing domestic violence, especially women and children. Urgent and unbureaucratic measures are needed to manage this crisis so that we can mobilise the available financial capacity to ensure the availability of the necessary medical equipment and protective equipment, the high research capacity and funding for drug and vaccine research. No one knows how long this crisis will last, but its economic and social consequences will be long-term and damaging. The Commission must therefore present a new and tailored multiannual financial perspective on strengthening social well-being and economic recovery. We must have a European guarantee for the child, the European scheme for reinsurance of unemployment benefits, the minimum wage, in order to ensure the safety of the most vulnerable people.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – The original aim of the decision was for the European Parliament to express its readiness to act unitedly in times of emergency to protect the lives of Europeans and to ensure that the European economy recovers as soon as possible after the epidemic. Unfortunately, only four factions gave their name to the text, as it was watered down by the left-wing forces and made the subject of an ideological struggle; the plan was thus thwarted, seriously weakening the legitimacy of the decision. Moreover, they have been intresed into subjects that have nothing to do with the original purpose, such as the relocation of migrants, the European Public Prosecutor's Office or the transition to majority decision-making. The text mentions Hungary and Poland in an unfavourable context, which in turn perform particularly well in the management of the coronavirus epidemic. It is unacceptable that the measures taken by the Hungarian Government are presented through serious material errors. This also destroys the credibility of the EP. The citizens of the European Union do not expect petty partisan political games from the European Parliament, but effective, swift and tangible measures that can help substantially combat the epidemic and the resulting economic crisis and alleviate the delays caused by the misjudgment of EU bodies. It is not necessary for the European Union to disguise the belated response by criticising certain Member States. This may be about human lives, not about the institutions bringing some Member States into disrepute under the pretext of ideological skirmishes.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – In both the preventive and the initial phase of the response to the new coronavirus pandemic, the EU has performed largely incoherent, shreathed and insufficiently determined. Since the establishment of a full quarantine in Italian Lombardy, the Wuhan scenario on European soil that no one expected (or wanted to anticipate), to date, there has been a clear shift, especially from reactive to a more proactive role for the whole EU. The second package of Commission proposals, which we are voting on in Parliament, is also confirmed by the fact that this role is in solidarity, both in terms of combating unemployment, in helping workers in small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as strengthening public health systems and the common civil protection mechanism. If European solidarity is important (and as it also appears to be effective) in the urgent collective response to the consequences of a pandemic, it will be existential in the response phase to the economic crisis and recession. This response must not, however, in any way sideline the idea of a European green deal, as this recklessly and irresponsibly advocates European conservative policy.  It is precisely the current crisis that points to certain fundamental anomalies of the economic system and the negative effects of its extremes. It also clearly highlights those areas where we undoubtedly need 'more Europe'. We must therefore start rebuilding the EU today so that we can build its future – a more unified, social and fair green.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Thank you to those who are fighting on all fronts caused by the pandemic. We stand firm for all those affected by the covid-19 virus. We welcome every gesture of solidarity between people and the international community.  After World War II, there was no situation so difficult and dangerous that it increasingly affects societies and economies around the world. Each country is fighting for the health and life of its citizens. Poland also faces the current situation by taking the necessary measures to defend its citizens, acting in accordance with the letter of the law. Unfortunately, this does not prevent politicians and European institutions from interfering even on ideological or philosophical issues, which are, after all, outside the competences of the European Union. I firmly believe that we have many more important topics that we must address together and individually within each country. What is it about attacking Polish and Hungary in such a biased way? For example, Hungary has been criticised for introducing a state of emergency. Poland, on the other hand, for not introducing such a state.  Our actions must be coordinated at international level. Let us focus on concrete actions that will help us to counteract the effects of the pandemic as much as possible, because unfortunately there are many indications that we still have a long and difficult fight ahead of us. Therefore, it is strange and incomprehensible to attack my country even in the present time.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – In the context of the current crisis, one of the priorities of the ITRE Committee is to protect Europe’s 25 million small and medium enterprises, as well as the sectors of industries most affected, including those sectors that are suffering from disruption of supply chains. Accordingly, I reinforce the call for a European horizontal strategy for SME recovery to support them by providing continuous access to finance, reducing red tape and fostering investments in strategic value chains. I express support for the reintegration of supply chains inside the EU and for the proposal for a Health Autonomy Action in strategic areas such as Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (API). In the same context, I highlight the importance of strengthening the competences, budget and staff of the ECDC and EMA, to enable these agencies to efficiently coordinate medical responses during crisis. I am conviced that the EU recovery package will have at its core enough financial resources. Finally, the COVID-19 crisis proved one more time the necessity to further integrate EU space programs Galileo and Copernicus. The added value of these systems along with the use of artificial intelligence play a decisive role in combating pandemics and crisis.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: in writing. – In the last three months, the European Parliament has been news of three things: for approving the 'climate emergency', for singing hand in hand when the United Kingdom left and for inviting Greta to give a conference in the middle of the pandemic, with the building closed even to state visits. These were the priorities of this Parliament until we were hit by Wuhan's coronavirus.  Now, the consensus groups are asking us to join a joint resolution proposal calling for even more powers and more bureaucratic bodies to the European Union to the detriment of nations. They haven't learned anything. If there is one thing this emergency has taught us, it is that, when it comes to truth, the institutions that are worth it are the family and the national community. They're the ones who're going to get us out of this crisis. We cannot continue to sacrifice these institutions at the altar of political correctness, bureaucracy and green pacts. Europe must help, not get in the way.  We will vote yes to financial aid to alleviate this emergency, or to investigate the role of the Chinese dictatorship in spreading this pandemic, but not to plans to advance the federalist agenda.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: in writing. – The EU is currently facing an unprecedented pandemic. The current situation has raised cross-cutting problems for all Member States, which translate into serious economic and social consequences. Every day we have seen the consequences caused by this public health crisis and realize that the health area is transversal to all areas of society. More than ever, it is imperative that the EU speaks with one voice. It is crucial to join forces and work towards the creation of a European Public Health Threat Mechanism. This mechanism will allow not only to monitor and prepare a coordinated response to any outbreaks that may arise in the EU, but also for ambitious social and economic planning in order to protect the different sectors, workers and families. It should be recalled that the Outermost Regions of the European Union (ORs) have very specific socio-economic characteristics, and more than ever it is necessary to pay increased attention to Article 349 TFEU. This article should be transversal to legislative matters in the various sectors. I hope that the European Commission will show strong signs of solidarity by developing concrete recovery, reconstruction and investment packages and measures to support the Economy of the ORs. United, we are stronger.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. – The Covid-19 pandemic represents the most serious and dramatic crisis that Europe has faced since the Second World War, with its very high human, economic and social costs.  The European Union has taken and must continue to take strong, immediate and concrete initiatives to ensure coordinated and effective action to combat the pandemic and its consequences. This is necessary, not only to provide immediate care and assistance to citizens, but also to reduce the impact on the economic and social fabric of the Member States, and to prevent the crisis from becoming a criminal issue.  Like any crisis, this is likely to represent an opportunity for criminal organisations, which are very skilled at exploiting social hardship and economic difficulties. We must prevent organised criminal groups from using their huge resources and liquidity to win over companies and businesses in crisis, or from entering the protective equipment business, taking advantage of the scarcity of supply.  For these reasons too, it is necessary for the European Union to use every margin for action to ensure that Member States have the opportunity to concretely support workers and companies and to create a coordinated and effective system for the purchase and distribution of essential goods in the fight against coronavirus.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. – The EU and European citizens are experiencing an unprecedented crisis due to the crown. Unfortunately, we are measuring huge human losses, and there are starting to be particularly negative economic impacts. The EU must intervene immediately and decisively to address the coming economic crisis. From the out0s we stressed the importance of issuing a Eurobond as the most appropriate economic instrument to deal with the coming downturn in the European economy. The EU must rise to the occasion, prove in practice that we are a truly United Europe, with solidarity and common objectives. If, at these critical times, the EU lags behind and does not live up to citizens' expectations, it will not just lose a battle, and the European construction itself is likely to be at risk.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – The EU must make up for its delay in responding to the COVID-19 crisis, as has been admitted by the European Commission President herself. We need a European Union that welcomes ambitious plans and adopts mature efforts that show citizens that EU growth, protection, solidarity and support are not selective. The mistakes of the 2008 financial crisis cannot be repeated. The Green Deal must be at the recovery plan’s core. Developing a long-term sustainable economy plan will make the EU more resilient and will further strengthen the social pillar. We need as a matter of urgency a strong protection net to support the most vulnerable and our workers, self-employed and SMEs. The joint procurement of medical supplies at the EU level, especially for smaller Member States like Malta, is vital and it must be ensured when the COVID19 vaccine becomes available. The pandemic has accentuated the bloc’s vulnerabilities. Amidst the crisis, irregular migration continues. For years we urged for a common response, and in the most time of need, this is not happening. Malta, Italy and Greece cannot be left alone. Pledges must be honoured and to be believed solidarity must not remain words on paper but be effectively implemented.

name: Johan DANIELSSON
text: Written. "The ongoing corona crisis demonstrates the importance of a well-functioning transport system. Transport is needed to provide essential medicines and food, but also to secure our economy. This applies to all EU countries. Our common internal market and our common rules are a force in times of crisis. I am therefore pleased that the European Parliament is now adopting a position on the EU's handling of the corona crisis, which emphasises the importance of the EU transport system, but also of the health and safety of workers. A safe working environment should be available in all sectors. We must ensure a good working environment both for those workers who work during the current crisis, and for those who are now going back to their workplace. If we expect workers to start the economy again step by step, they must be able to rely on the fact that no economic factors or profit shortcuts will erode their safety. No one should have to worry about putting their health at risk when working and taking responsibility. The European Commission should provide guidelines on how to ensure a safe working environment when restarting the economy, and ensure that Member States and employers comply with the EU rules in this area.

name: Margarita DE LA PISA CARRIÓN
text: in writing. – The Wuhan virus crisis has shown that, despite the EU's good intentions, its heavy machinery prevents it from acting quickly and effectively, from the centralized purchase of protective equipment to the creation of green corridors. The lack of initial coordination and the different national approaches implemented transformed the principle of solidarity into an individualistic vision, paralyzing the internal market and making it difficult to supply basic goods to deal with the pandemic, such as gloves, tests and masks.  The situation remains dramatic, especially among our elders, abandoned by the society for which they worked and often depriving them of treatments on grounds of age, condemning them to death. We need to focus our efforts on health and saving lives.  Until then, economic activity will not be able to function properly, but we cannot be late or short. Community priorities need to be reoriented in order to adapt them to reality. It is necessary to guarantee liquidity to SMEs and self-employed people and reduce or eliminate taxes so that they can survive the crisis, as they have seen their collection have fallen to zero. Otherwise, they will disappear forever and, with them, jobs.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Writing. – I thank the Commission for the report and, in particular, thank you for the sincere and sometimes self-critical words. I also hear the critical comments of the Member States – I am not talking about the Hungarian Government, which reflexively always scolds the European institutions for everything – and I confess that I am more understanding of the Commission. This situation is unprecedented not only for the 460 million European citizens, but also for the Commission. Although the Member States would sometimes be self-critical, as the President of the Commission was today. Nevertheless, after the initial uncertainty, the Commission quickly found itself and put excellent proposals on the table. It is not the Commission's responsibility to have no more serious responsibilities in the field of health in the event of such a pandemic. All powers are with the Member States, and I am saddened that some Member States go against the recommendations and then blame the European Union for their own failures. However, it can already be seen that it is not possible to effectively defeat pandemics by different methods from one Member State to another. The main conclusion of this dramatic situation should be that we must join forces. We must create a Health Union that entrusts the European Union with the fight against major epidemics beyond individual and local diseases and creates the financial and institutional conditions for this. More than anything, this epidemic and crisis shows how dependent we are on each other. We're going to be a lot stronger as a single man.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. The apologies given to Italy for those in Europe who have been absent and deaf to its requests for solidarity have made it clear that the European Union is la late in promoting coordinated action to combat Covid-19 and its health and socio-economic consequences. Some Member States should take an example from what millions of European citizens, showing responsibility for complying with the containment rules, have learned for a long time: we need to protect each other in order to better protect themselves and those who need them most. The well-being of the whole EU depends on the well-being of each Member State. Those same citizens are also looking to the European institutions to obtain the necessary protections to deal with the crisis, mitigate the impact of the pandemic and restart the economy. It is time for the EU to put aside mistrust and national divisions, to show that it is a Community in which no one should fall behind. Have the courage and ambition to follow the path indicated by Italy and other states: recovery and reconstruction need not only existing funds and financial instruments, but also more resources to access through an innovative "Recovery Fund", a fund with common European securities to finance the most affected countries.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – Despite the propaganda, the resolution discussed at this session does not depart from the positions taken so far by the other EU institutions, confirming a framework marked by the total lack of solidarity and the shortcomings in the response to the consequences of COVID-19. The crisis we are talking about here was already in gestation, and it was inseparable from the consequences of EU policies and guidelines. The implications associated with the COVID-19 outbreak detonated it, gave it new and unexpected contours, aggravated it. COVID-19 is a huge public health problem, with enormous economic and social consequences. But these consequences, the impacts on workers and peoples, depend on the economic and social context in which the response to the pandemic is operated. Under capitalism, as is demonstrated, these consequences will always be more painful for the overwhelming majority of the population than what would be necessary. The situation faced by workers and peoples requires significant measures of public investment in the protection of health, the social protection of the most affected and disadvantaged, the defence of wages and employment with rights, and the relaunch of economic activity. The breadth and depth of the necessary response requires releasing the constraints imposed by the EU and recovering the essential spheres of sovereignty of states.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The pandemic does not change the existing security risks. Actors such as Russia, China and Iran continue cyber attacks and disinformation campaigns. Ukrainian soldiers are still killed in Donbass. In occupied Crimea, repression against the Tatars continue. No one is responsible for the health of the inhabitants of the occupied Georgian regions. The Assad regime, with the support of the Kremlin, is committing further crimes without sparing hospitals. These countries are trying to use international forums to strengthen their position. By manipulating the facts, Russia is seeking the lifting of sanctions. China, which has long camouflaged the scale of the threat, is conducting a large-scale image campaign. Instead of seeking Beijing's considerations, we should pay more attention to learning about the good practices and experiences of our Asian democratic partners, such as Taiwan and South Korea.  I regret that no word has been made on these issues by the Commission today. We have also heard too little about the role of other organisations, including NATO, whose aircraft, equipment and specialists serve our societies today. I also lacked information on support for research into the development of vaccines and medicines – which, after all, is most important for overcoming the pandemic – including cooperation with the US, which houses the world's most modern and largest research laboratories. I agree with my Italian colleague Raffael Fitt, who has warned that the Commission and the EU institutions should not run away from responsibility for their mistakes and omissions through political attacks on Member States, including Poland.

name: Emmanouil FRAGKOS
text: Writing. – the time has come when Europe must show its solidarity and ensure the well-being of its citizens. Immediate must be our response to the problems of the economy, with our eyes on the next day. The primary sector must be strengthened and protected. Small and medium-sized enterprises are at risk of disintegration. In addition to direct payments, Member States are invited to ensure the necessary liquidity for the following day. Citizens who have lost their income find it difficult to meet even their basic needs. We have a duty to ensure that basic goods are not missed by any citizen of Europe as a result of the pandemic. The health systems of the Member States are being tested hard. So do all sectors of the economy, such as tourism, industry, fisheries, trade.  As the European Union we must ensure that this necessary financing of the Member States' economy does not create a new major debt crisis. We are calling for measures to write off the new debt, measures that will help our economies grow and grow in the long term. We are opposed to half-measures and borrowing, because that is how we exorcise the problem, so that we can find it in front of us later inflated and unmanageable.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – A decision on coordinated action to combat the coronavirus epidemic would have been much needed if it were really about what it should be about, saving lives, cooperation and solidarity. Unfortunately, however, it does not make good on the hopes it brings, because it is once again being made an ideological struggle by a majority in Parliament. Mantra-like, it repeatedly shames Hungary and Poland, two Member States that perform particularly well in the management of the coronavirus epidemic compared to other Member States. It is completely unacceptable and shows its ideological orientation, demonstrating the double standard of condemning the measures taken by the Hungarian Government on the basis of serious factual errors (false claims). This is destroying the credibility of the EP as an institution. The citizens of the European Union do not expect petty partisan political games from the European Parliament, but effective, swift and tangible measures that can meaningfully help to combat the epidemic and the resulting economic crisis and alleviate the delays caused by the misjudgment of EU bodies. It is not necessary for the European Union to disguise the belated response to the crisis caused by the epidemic by criticising certain Member States. We're talking about human lives here.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: Writing. – The original aim of the decision was for the European Parliament to express its readiness to act unitedly in times of emergency to protect the lives of Europeans and to ensure that the European economy recovers as soon as possible after the epidemic. Unfortunately, only four factions gave their name to the text, as it was watered down by the left-wing forces and made the subject of an ideological struggle; the plan was thus thwarted, seriously weakening the legitimacy of the decision. Moreover, they have been intresed into subjects that have nothing to do with the original purpose, such as the relocation of migrants, the European Public Prosecutor's Office or the transition to majority decision-making. The text mentions Hungary and Poland in an unfavourable context, which in turn perform particularly well in the management of the coronavirus epidemic. It is unacceptable that the measures taken by the Hungarian Government are presented through serious material errors. This also destroys the credibility of the EP. The citizens of the European Union do not expect petty partisan political games from the European Parliament, but effective, swift and tangible measures that can help substantially combat the epidemic and the resulting economic crisis and alleviate the delays caused by the misjudgment of EU bodies. It is not necessary for the European Union to disguise the belated response by criticising certain Member States. This may be about human lives, not about the institutions bringing some Member States into disrepute under the pretext of ideological skirmishes.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – The fight against the coronavirus pandemic has been going on for more than a month. The pandemic has fundamentally changed the daily lives of European citizens, who have adapted responsibly to the new situation. The European Union must also rise to the task. It is therefore necessary to rethink the strategies so far in many areas to address the crisis. The coronavirus has highlighted the vulnerability of the Union. It has emerged that, for a number of key industrial and health value chains, Member States need the help of external actors. A new industrial strategy is needed, in which increasing the strategic autonomy of the European Union must be of paramount importance. SMEs, family farms and individual businesses provide a livelihood for around 100 million people across Europe. Therefore, their survival is a guarantee of the survival of the European economy. We need a new SME strategy that prioritises support for the businesses most at risk of crisis, taking into account the specificities of the Member States. Finally, successful crisis management can only be made by respecting each other. It is not time for political debates and instroversion of differences. We must now devote all our energy to the fight for the health, well-being and safety of citizens. This is the key to ensuring that the Union finds itself as soon as possible after the epidemic, which is in the common interest of all of us.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: Writing. – Needless to say, the COVID-19 pandemic has created an unprecedented crisis that the Union itself will only survive if it is united and helpful to states and citizens. A number of measures approved last month are adding more to tie the hands of governments to take effective action to help them overcome difficulties in the health service and the economy. A number of measures were due to come a few weeks earlier. We need to address acute problems, but we must also prepare today for the day after the corona crisis and also for the fact that this crisis may not be the last. It is therefore also necessary to discuss strengthening the EU's competences in the field of health, which would allow for a faster response and more effective coordination of national action from the outset. I believe that the €3 billion earmarked for the provision of medical equipment, the creation of strategic medical supplies will be felt by citizens as soon as possible in the form of direct aid, and thanks to the number of measures taken, economies will be gradually restarted. However, priority must be given not only to the invention of a vaccine as soon as possible, but also to examine all available medicines and treatments, the application of which might save the lives of several of the thousands of dying Europeans. Information must be exchanged and procedures that have proven to be effective must be shared. Coordinated action must also be reflected by the Member States in the intended relaxation of measures restricting the economy and social relations.

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, the decision to take concerted action to combat the coronavirus epidemic is not live up to its expectations. It is regrettable that only the four EP factions have joined the joint decision, which seriously weakens its legitimacy and credibility. It is particularly regrettable that the text mentions Hungary and Poland, two Member States that perform particularly well in the management of the coronavirus epidemic, in an unfavourable context compared to other Member States. It is also retent in itself that the text names specific Member States instead of general observations, and it is completely unacceptable that it presents the measures taken by the Hungarian Government through serious material errors. This is destroying the credibility of the EP as an institution and issuing a certificate of the ep's left-wing and liberal factions. The citizens of the European Union do not expect petty partisan political games from the European Parliament, but effective, swift and tangible measures that can meaningfully help to combat the epidemic and the resulting economic crisis and alleviate the delays caused by the misjudgment of EU bodies. It is not necessary for the European Union to disguise the belated response to the crisis caused by the epidemic by criticising certain Member States. This is about lives, not which institutions in which Member State takes the necessary decisions.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Writing. – The epidemic situation in Europe has presented new challenges for our continent. In addition to our elderly fellow human beings, the most vulnerable people living in difficult financial circumstances, especially our Fellow Roma, are most at risk of viral disease. They face extraordinary economic and social difficulties, and for many of them their daily livelihoods have been impossible. Assistance through the FEAD fund is unavoidable. To this day, many Roma communities in Europe are victims of discrimination, their colonies are not provided with general sanitation, clean drinking water and hot food are shortages. I therefore welcome the European Commission's proposal to provide assistance directly and locally through the FEAD fund. The delivery of food, clothing and other personal items should be a top priority, which is why I call on the Commission to develop and enforce appropriate control mechanisms. I particularly welcome the fact that, in view of the current situation, the fund can also be used for the division of protective equipment. Access to the right equipment is still a major concern for the most deprived persons in the European Union. However, all this is inevitable for successful epidemiological control. I would further ask the Commission to provide the most technical support to ngos involved in practical assistance, but not to allow abuse of the fund. In these difficult moments, we cannot let go of the hands of our fellow men in distress.

name: Virginie JORON
text: In writing. Instead of slashing French savings, why not focus on advertising spending to save our TPEs? Some merchants, craftsmen, restaurateurs, hoteliers and the self-employed suffer dramatically from the confinement triggered by the unpreparedness of the French government.  While the Brussels Commission is talking about a plan of 3 trillion euros, the amending budgets actually voted in the European Parliament on 17 April are 1000 times smaller. Brussels dreams of thousands of billions free, printed in Luxembourg or Frankfurt but who will pay the bill or platinum guarantees? Instead of raising taxes on the French, or even seizing 10% of their savings as the IMF (International Monetary Fund) might advocate, it would be wise for states to focus on non-essential spending.  Advertising spending is 100 billion euros in the media in Europe and 8% of the turnover of insurance companies. An exceptional contribution of 40% on advertising spending could be a way to explore to identify tens of billions of euros. Very small businesses with 20 or fewer employees need to receive our support as a priority.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: in writing. – I welcome the roadmap presented by the Commission as I consider European coordination in lifting of containment measures desirable. I want to highlight especially the mass testing as the key priority in containing the outbreak. We have to be prepared that the coronavirus can stay with us for more than a couple of months. Therefore, mass testing, including contact tracing of infected persons, and randomized testing of population to look for new clusters, provide great value for money. South Korea is a perfect example that identifying the outbreak early enough can prevent both loss of lives and vast economic damage. Expanded testing capacity and harmonized methodology can help us identify any new local outbreaks in the real time. That could be very beneficial also later in the year, in case a new wave of spreading would come in the winter. With mass and systematic testing the Member States could identify and quarantine a smaller area of their affected territory early enough to limit the health and economic damage without the need for closing their borders. I therefore think that the concept of local quarantines is also worth analyzing.

name: Radan KANEV
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, I support the EP resolution on EU policy to tackle the pandemic and its economic consequences. This resolution is bold and timely, especially in paragraphs 17, 20 and 21, which call for more funds in the multiannual financial framework for a direct budgetary programme to recover the EU from the crisis.  The so-called 'European Marshall Plan' for exiting the coronavirus crisis can only take place if Member States understand that sound budget support is needed, not just exceptional measures by the ECB and other credit programmes. The green recovery policy, which includes the modernisation of European energy and industry in the bailout package, also requires direct BUDGET support from the EU.  The only thing missing from this resolution is the clear demand that the EP will not back down from its positions on the EP budget. That these are not yet another empty "calls" and "demands", but a firm and firm political stance in defence of EU citizens and the most affected regions, small businesses and families. Today is the time for the European Parliament to show that it is not a spokesman or advisory body, but a true representative of europe's citizens and a guarantor of EU unity. Thank you!

name: Pierre KARLESKIND
text: In writing. The European Union is facing the most serious health crisis in its history. Every day, in the four corners of our Union, carers are courageously adapting to the evolution of a deadly virus, still unknown in December. Added to this health crisis is an economic crisis that is on an unprecedented scale.  This historic situation calls for a historic European response. With this resolution, the European Parliament is up to the task. Beyond our national borders and political divides, we have reached an unprecedented and ambitious agreement.  Ambitious solidarity, calling for European obligations, guaranteed by our common budget, that will allow the most affected countries to continue to finance themselves. Climate ambitious, putting the European Green Pact and climate neutrality at the heart of our recovery strategy. Ambitious, finally on our values, condemning the authoritarian excesses of the Polish and Hungarian governments, which are using the crisis to flout the fundamental principles of the rule of law.  Parliament is leading the way. Heads of state and government must rise to the occasion by following it, so that these health and economic crises do not add up to a political crisis. It is about the survival of our Union.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The current situation of the COVID-19 pandemic has triggered an unprecedented crisis at many different levels of socio-economic life across Europe and most countries around the world. The fight against the effects of a pandemic is a national responsibility, but the European Union should be involved in supporting its Member States, in particular their medical services and the staff on the front line of the fight against the pandemic.  A comprehensive approach and coordinated action by the European Union is needed to provide the necessary assistance to those most vulnerable and needy citizens and services that are extremely burdened by the crisis. It is also necessary for the European Union to allocate significant resources to scientific research in order to develop a vaccine and medicines against COVID-19. This is a situation that requires swift but sensible and decisive action.  The way to combat the pandemic is to stop the operation of, among other things, almost the entire area of services. The impact of the pandemic on the economic situation of the countries affected is difficult to predict, but it is certain that the longer the pandemic lasts, the more serious the damage caused by it will be. The European Union should actively contribute to taking action to minimise the inevitable economic crisis. This is a challenge and an examination for the European Union, which should be based on the principles of partnership, but also on subsidiarity, as set out in the Treaties.

name: Izabela-Helena KLOC
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Today, more than half a million Europeans are infected with Covid-19 coronavirus. In addition to the fatalities, this unprecedented crisis has serious economic and social consequences, the scale of which we are still unable to determine. We ask the European Commission to re-examine the priorities for the European Green Deal and to temporarily put down this project. At present, our primary responsibility is to provide adequate resources, facilities and conditions to guarantee the safety of medical services and patients.  Furthermore, we must prepare for the inevitable financial crisis and find solutions to mitigate its effects. For 2020, the IMF expects a negative growth rate of 6.1% (-7.5% in the euro area) in developed economies. The whole pandemic mitigation process must be accompanied by targeted fiscal and monetary policy.  The EU's most important task now is to show solidarity with the Member States, even at the cost of putting off pre-crisis m.in on climate policy. We call on the Commission to maintain pragmatism and to treat this global crisis with due seriousness. The EU's response to the pandemic depends on the fate of every European citizen.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The title of today's debate is 'Coordinated EU action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its effects'. Let us strongly emphasise one word in this title: 'coordinated'.  In the Eurosceptic media and on the lips of Eurosceptic politicians, accusations against the EU in recent weeks that it has done too little in this difficult time is 'not passing the test'. This is not true, of course, but it does not bother the opponents of the Union – they place their short-sighted political interest above the facts and the long-term interest of Europe. I would therefore like to remind them that the European Union is not only the EU institutions such as Parliament, the Commission or the Court of Justice. It is also the Council of the EU or the European Council that make up the Member States. And they are responsible for how these institutions work.  The pandemic has shown us that all the institutions of the Union at all levels must work together, that states and regions must cooperate, that action must be coordinated, that we need closer integration, and that a 'Europe of homelands' is a recipe for nationalist and selfish behaviour by governments that are reluctant to the Union.  By the way, Eurosceptic governments such as Polish, when making accusations of inademn against the EU, benefit widely from EU aid, but do not want to inform citizens about it – e.g. part of the Polish 'anti-crisis shield' is directly EU funds.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – A number of effective measures are needed at European level in relation to the epidemic. Support for the most deprived persons should not be interrupted due to the risk of infection. The crisis poses a greater risk to the most vulnerable, who experience deprivation in everyday life if we do not help quickly, flexibly, adapting to the situation. Member States should also ensure that the poorest receive food and other basic consumer goods (e.g. footwear, soap) during the epidemic. It is necessary to respond to everyday challenges, not only in theory, but also in a way that is life-like. It is important to change the rules of the European Assistance Fund for the most deprived persons in an urgent procedure: due to the epidemic and the rules on distance, a new way of allocating food must be found; People can't gather in a free kitchen like before. There needs to be a change in how help is delivered: delivering unit packages or handing out vouchers is now a better way. However, in some countries (including my country) the division of electronic vouchers is counter-appropriate: flexibility and adapting to the specificities of the Member States are needed. Proper protective equipment is currently required for the distribution of food: I welcome the fact that the fund will be used to distribute anti-epidemic protective equipment in addition to the distribution of food and basic financial support, with 100% EU funding temporarily. I would like to express my opposition to the fact that some of my fellow Members are concerned with the rule of law of the Hungary the protection of the lives of EU citizens.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Easter holidays are behind us. Many of us were forced to spend it without families, friends, without church and sacraments. We have a long way to go, but we will succeed and deal with the coming crisis. Although, observing the economic and social consequences, I am very concerned about what the future holds. Underfunded and overburdened health care, people without jobs, failing businesses and factories. We are facing an economic recession that will affect all aspects of life. Let us show common sense, credibility and competence at a time of unprecedented crisis. Our task at the moment is to mobilise support measures for European citizens who are desperate for help. However, this is only the first step on our way to overcoming the crisis that we will all face. It is to be hoped that lessons will be learned in the future, a new way of thinking will arise and the necessary reforms will be introduced in the EU as well as in the Member States.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – EU countries have been affected by the coronavirus pandemic, which after only 2 months of its duration is hundreds of thousands infected and tens of thousands of victims, as well as the deepest economic crisis. While health is a competence of the Member States, the European institutions failed in the first weeks of the pandemic and the countries most affected did not receive EU assistance.  The image that was probably remembered by Europeans was the situation in March, when a plane from China with medical supplies landed at Rome airport while the Italians were waiting for planes from Brussels or Berlin. The EU's iliability is firstly issued after the 2009 crisis. recommendations on the need for Member States to make savings by decommissioning hospital beds, resulting in the elimination in the EU of as many as 14% of all respirator beds and, secondly, the fact that in 2020 truck drivers from Central European countries are being lobstered to secure the continuity of supply of goods across the EU in order to 'kick' them out of the European market with a mobility package after 2021.  There was also optimism in today's speeches that the EU will deal with the crisis, including in the economy, by mobilising hundreds of billions of euros, but the conclusions are worrying. All indications are that the way to deal with the Union's problems is to be more Union and more ideological wars, including with countries whose governments in Brussels are disliked.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – Unfortunately, the COVID-19 pandemic continues to take lives, and even though one third of the world is in social isolation, the number of infected people is increasing every day. This human tragedy that the pandemic has brought to Europeans and their families and to citizens all over the globe has to be urgently addressed by a coordinated global action. But first and foremost, all future actions taken by Member States have to be guided by the Union’s founding principle of solidarity and loyal cooperation. The COVID 19 crisis has accentuated the importance of joint European action and we must mobilise our common resources to fight the pandemic and its consequences. Therefore, I call on the Commission to strengthen all components of crisis management and disaster response, and to further strengthen instruments such as RescEU to ensure a truly common, coordinated and effective response at EU level. We immediately need to do more for SMEs, help them maintain jobs and manage their liquidity. The European Commission has to propose a massive recovery and reconstruction package for investment to support the European economy after the crisis, beyond what the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Central Bank (ECB) are already doing.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. – The scope and magnitude of the consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic are unparalleled in the history of our democracies. The European political system as a whole has to be overcome and its added value demonstrated. The Commission and Parliament continue to work and seek within their competence all the measures necessary to minimise these effects. The joint resolution proposal negotiated by the four main European political groups clearly represents a united and decisive response to a shared crisis. Parliament assumes this historic responsibility and calls on the Commission for a massive recovery and reconstruction package, with investments to support the European economy after the crisis, beyond what the European Stability Mechanism, the EIB and the ECB are already doing. We are talking about a new, more ambitious investment plan that allows direct support for SMEs and the re-industrialization of Europe.  If there is one lesson we must draw from this crisis, it is that we have to re-produce in Europe. This is clear to citizens, entrepreneurs and many politicians, who will respond with determination by unlocking all the economic support needed to make that happen.

name: César LUENA
text: in writing. – The crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic goes beyond a health crisis, presents challenges at all levels and the potential impact on all sectors of society remains to be determined. This crisis affects all countries and knows no borders. Thousands of lives have been claimed around the world and millions of households will suffer the long-term consequences.  That is why we European Socialists are demanding coordinated and strong action from the EU, which has citizens and their fundamental rights at their centre. We call for the protection of the most vulnerable so that no one is left behind and a recovery with the Green Pact and digital transformation at its base. We also call on the European Commission and the Council for a 'large-scale recovery and reconstruction package' to support the European economy after the crisis, as well as 'recovery bonds guaranteed by the EU budget'. The EU must live up to the circumstances.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – At a time when the coronavirus pandemic is on the rise, the European Union is considering measures to support individual economic sectors and Member States are introducing aid arrangements to mitigate the effects of the crisis on domestic companies operating in the common European market.  However, we must not forget consumers, who are an essential part of the functioning of the market. What about their rights? What steps will we take to protect them in these difficult times? The COVID-19 crisis is an opportunity for UTPs. What action does the Commission intend to take to protect European consumers from imports of personal protective equipment and medical equipment of questionable quality from China?  More and more so-called fake news appears on social media and online portals, introducing informational mischips and making the fight against COVID-19 more difficult. We cannot count on the goodwill of the owners of social networks and social media. We must take the fight against lies on the web and protect its users.  What about protecting airline passengers and travel agency customers who bought their services before the global lockdown? Does the Commission have in the plan the implementation of safeguard mechanisms for these groups?  What about borrowers who, because of COVID-19, find themselves in a difficult situation and have trouble paying their debts?  There are many questions and few answers. It is time to take real action.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. – It is good to see the EU's response to the COVID-19 crisis being ramped up this week, with additional funding for EU healthcare systems, flexibility for Member States to use EU funds to respond to the crisis, support for fisheries and aquaculture, and a delay in the implementation of the new medical devices regulation so the sector can focus on providing vital equipment at this time. The European Parliament has adapted its working methods, with MEPs participating remotely from across the EU. As a Parliament it is essential for us to keep working to represent our citizens’ concerns and scrutinising action in response to this crisis. That means criticising the response when necessary. The EU and Member States should have been quicker to react to the situation in Italy, the first Member State severely affected by COVID-19. But it also means highlighting positives, like the EU institutions working to ensure better coordination among Member States on issues including movement of goods and medical supplies. Over the coming weeks we need to see the EU coordinating the actions of Member States as they lift some restrictions. However, we should not be complacent. The virus has not gone away.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Writing. – The word "rescue package" is currently widely used by governments – perhaps because it has a reassuring sound for many citizens. The stupid thing is that every "rescue" must be paid for by taxpayers. There is no doubt that the current situation has not been present in recent history, and it therefore requires special measures. These include grants and short-term aid loans, which we too have given our assent to. Being able to repay them in the coming years and decades will be an enormous effort, especially for the tax-paying citizens. This is an act of strength that the rulers like to conceal from these citizens when they are currently celebrating themselves in the media light as active saviors. In view of the huge sums, it is necessary to tell taxpayers clearly what it will cost to save Italy, Spain and co. And that we can't afford it at all.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – The COVID-19 epidemic and the subsequent economic and social crisis make it even clearer that a coordinated common response to global challenges needs to be provided. The European Union is taking action by focusing an astonishing amount of resources on dealing with health and economic problems. A number of bills are currently awaiting a vote on ₋ including the economy, health and financial assistance to various areas of the crisis, ₋ the aquaculture sector. Solidarity between some Member States is unquestionable, but others, like Viktor Orban, use this tragic situation to consolidate its power and suppress Hungarian citizens. In breach of the obligations arising from the EU Treaties, at the end of March it ordered the maintenance of the state of emergency for an unlimited period and, with it, the regulation of governance. It is outrageous that, while tens of thousands of people are dying, authoritarian leaders in power are making infringing provisions that do not contribute at all to controlling the epidemic and tresuming the health and economic crisis resulting from the epidemic. Let us not allow European citizens to suffer because of irresponsible, power-hungry political leaders, so I would therefore ask my fellow Members to vote in favour of the proposal condemning the Orban government.

name: Andżelika Anna MOŻDŻANOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The next weeks of the gruelling fight against COVID-19 – the fight for human health, but also the survival of millions of businesses and jobs in Europe – make us aware of how hard we need to work and how to approach the fight holistically. The revaluation of priorities must take place immediately. How far we are from a real impact assessment of our legislative decisions shows the mobility package. Now that every hour counts, drivers are not forced to rest, and all bans are no longer relevant. Trucks carrying security measures, medicines and food ensure continuity of supply chains, the diversification of which is also essential for Europe to become independent from third countries.  I appeal for common sense when creating the law. Entrepreneurs do not need bureaucracy, but real, simple help. There will be no development in any area unless we protect workers from losing their jobs and businesses from bankruptcy. The COVID-19 pandemic cannot exacerbate the differences between Member States. Let us remember the principles of equality and justice.  We must ensure transfers between cohesion policy funds in order to support health, social and economic activities by freeing up all resources. Whether or not a country is in the euro area, it should have fair and rapid access to aid. The European Union needs common crisis management solutions covering all aspects of life: health, work, entrepreneurship, science, new technologies. And urgently!

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – Cooperation and coordination between Member States is essential to bring Europe out of the corona crisis. It would be sensible to phase out anti-virus prevention measures so that what has been done so far does not prove futile and countries do not have to face a new wave of disease.  The European Green Agreement is the best way to get out of the crisis, as it will help to stimulate the economy and create new jobs. It will also help to continue the fight against climate change, as global warming and environmental concerns have not gone away during the corona crisis.  A time of crisis requires responsibility for society as a whole. It is up to governments to find a balance point as the basis for their decisions. Account must be taken of both the state and trend of the spread of the comavirus, as well as the short-term and long-term effects on human health, as well as the limited access to health care in other diseases and ills. It has a price for human health.  It is also necessary to take much more seriously the impact of the economic downturn caused by the restrictions on the state and society as a whole, as well as on people. Loss of work and income will also affect people's health – both physical and mental. A reasoning analysis is needed that takes into account all relevant aspects and a decision that is based on it, which is reasonable and where there should be a balance point between the different risks. Governments must not underestimate the level of social stress and the concerns of many people about the health and economic situation of themselves and those close to them.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: in writing. – The coordinated EU action discussed at this session is nothing more than propaganda and remains in line with the positions taken so far, confirming the total lack of solidarity and limitations in responding to the consequences of COVID-19. It essentially fails, in essence, ignoring the scale of economic and social cohesion that will have to be linked to the response to the consequences of COVID-19, under penalty of further aggravating inequalities between Member States (MS) dug up over the years. COVID-19, being a huge public health problem, already shows enormous economic and social consequences to be addressed in view of the needs of workers, micro, small and medium-sized entrepreneurs and the country, in particular in terms of the social protection of the most affected and disadvantaged, the defence of employment and public services, support for the productive sectors , combating the external dependence of some MS, and the relaunch of economic activity. The solutions presented by the EU are more indebted to states, to the legitimacy of lay-off, without a concrete response to many of the problems faced by workers. A full response must necessarily be to release the constraints imposed by the EU and to recover state sovereignty instruments.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. – The Commission has drawn up a good exit plan, which the Member States must now follow. The lifting of restrictive measures must avoid the various europe-wide errors that have been detected in their erection and without cooperation. Now is the time for member states to coordinate together, using the same criteria and following the same logic. The virus is global, so our operations must also be cross-border. Science must be given a key role and the recommendations of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) and the WHO must be listened to. The importance of information when considering measures is essential. This is a new virus, but information is available and the situational picture is constantly updated. If the excessively rapid lifting of restrictions fails, we will have another wave of diseases on our backs, which is a worse option in many times, both humanly and economically. Timing is essential as we go into consider phasing out containment measures. Disassembly must start with measures with local impacts and gradually extended to a wider geographical area. Returning to the workplace must be phased in so that organisations can adapt to the increasing activity. On the basis of an analysis based on the number of infections, acceleration and existing healthcare capacity, a common European line will be established. It is clear that if you do not deliver carefully in a country and move too quickly, the risk of a re-escalation of the epidemic is real throughout Europe. We have seen how the virus knows no borders when it comes to countries or continents. Mr President, the coronavirus crisis has at the latest shown that we need a European Communicable Diseases Regulation and a proper agency to deal with it on a scientific basis.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Written. – People must be at the heart of the fight against coronavirus and its consequences. This is reflected by the PvdA in this resolution. That is one of the reason why we are voting in favour.  But there's more. Parliament has stipulated that the money released must benefit various sectors, populations and regions, including the overseas kingdoms. The PvdA's line that aid should not be used for bonuses or dividend payments to shareholders has been adopted. On the other hand, financial support for workers who are partially unemployed will be provided and the Green Deal remains a priority.  We are also stronger together in producing and distributing medical equipment, vaccines and medicines. It is essential that countries recognise that they are dependent on each other in this crisis: that is why we support proposals, such as recovery bonds. We have also seen member states, such as Hungary, use this crisis to erode democracy. For us, that is completely unacceptable. We are pleased that debt relief for developing countries is part of this resolution. Finally, attention is paid to the most vulnerable, such as women and children who are victims of violence. They always deserve our support, crisis or not.

name: Manuel PIZARRO
text: in writing. – The Covid-19 pandemic is one of those rare historical events whose impact can be said to be civilizational: it froze social relations, paralyzed the economy and put us before the unknown. While it rediscovers our fragility and strikes a severe blow to technoscientific self-confidence, this pandemic highlights the unity of the human species and the globalization of biopolitics. For the European Union, this is a challenge of such magnitude that it can only result in either its refoundation or its disintegration. In fact, the Union will only come out of this trial if it quickly take bold steps and driven by reciprocity. This joint resolution lists some of these steps, calling on the EU to overcome prejudice and resistance to save as many lives as possible, and then save the economy and avoid a social calamity.  This will only be possible on the basis of solidarity and sharing in the short term, and in the medium and long term, through a recovery plan that is up to the circumstances, based on massive public investment, either through the drastic strengthening of existing resources and mechanisms, or through the creation of new resources and new mechanisms.

name: Elżbieta RAFALSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In her speech, the EC President called on Member States to make the most effective use of SURE, a new instrument developed by the Commission to protect Europeans from the risk of unemployment. How would this new mechanism be funded? From a special payroll tax or corporate tax or from contributions paid by Member States? We look forward to answering the question of whether the EC will propose a permanent unemployment reinsurance programme in the EU to help countries in the recovery phase after the COVID-19 epidemic. What legal solution does the EC intend to propose: a directive or a regulation?  Serious doubts are raised about the legitimacy of the introduction of the mobility package, the negative impact of which will be felt by the owners of transport companies in each European country. The application of the rules can lead to congestion in the movement of goods and bankruptcies of companies. Speaking of plans, it is impossible to ignore the Green Deal. We know that for many regions around industry, it will involve numerous redundancies. At a time of crisis and the projected rise in unemployment, is the Commission not concerned about the accumulation of regional unemployment? A pandemic affects everyone, but we see that the elderly and disabled are at the most risk of infection, and they can't always get help. It is also the elderly who are at the most risk of digital exclusion today and are deprived of the right of access to basic care services. Will the strategy for action for the elderly be redefined and, if so, when will it be presented?

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. – First of all, I want to thank everyone who puts their health at risk in the fight against the virus and ensures the provision of essential services to the population. Your sacrifice is essential to save lives and overcome this crisis. We have faced a situation that the current decision-makers have not experienced so far. However, the world has not stopped, both the Lithuanian authorities and the European Union are doing as much as possible in the current circumstances. The unity of the European Union and solidarity between states are very important factors in improving the efficiency of decisions and mitigating the consequences of a pandemic across Europe. This pandemic has shown that we need a unified European health crisis response mechanism to help protect citizens' health quickly and effectively. We also need a much more crisis-resistant, sustainable economy that is more flexible in the face of challenges and the production of essential goods and the supply of services. At the moment, Europe is too dependent on imports, even when most of the goods arriving could be produced or produced in our countries. The difficulties encountered are lower where local production, including agriculture and food production, is strong and developed. The crisis has affected everyone, so only joint action can help the economy recover. No country can be left behind, because this solidarity will be a key measure in terms of confidence in the Future of the European Union.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour of this resolution, fine-tuning the Parliament’s responses to the crisis.
