However I put on record the following reservations: --We might be grossly underestimating the medium term impact of the pandemic, health wise; as they now stand, there is little to no safety margin in resource measures on line that could compensate eventually for this; --We are likely underestimating the ripple effects resulting from the economic downturn as well as possibly its actual extent, even if the public health situation improves overall according to the available best case scenarios; --The financial ‘bazooka’ being used on a European level is not (big) impressive enough, even if added to the national efforts by member state governments, especially when compared with that of the US. Moreover the way it was negotiated and agreed betrays the lack of a common vision regarding the objectives that are being set; --The so-called north-south controversy is obscuring the probability that contrary to the 2008 financial crisis, knock-on and knockdown effects will this time swing from south to north, vice versa, and back, since both production and demand have been hit deeply within our single market which over the last ten years, has become increasingly services oriented.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: in writing. – With this joint resolution, we give a first answer to the question: what EU do we want, or are we able to build, after the crisis generated by Covid19? We have overcome political differences and national interests and, by honouring the democratic power conferred on us by the popular vote, we affirm the option for a Europe based on the values of solidarity and democracy, where no country, region, or citizen will be left behind. If the pandemic is egalitarian, its effects are not. Therefore, it is important to curb division-generating imbalances. We need a resolute response capable of generating hope in citizens and relaunching the European economy on the basis of an Economic Recovery Plan anchored in sustainability, digitisation and combating inequalities. This requires mobilising the necessary resources through the pooling of debt issuance in the form of Eurobonds, Coronabonds or Recoverybonds - efficiency is important - and a new robust and flexible Multiannual Financial Framework. But it's not just the economy that needs to be revitalized. Democracy also needs that. We therefore stress that we reject any attempt to use the pandemic to restrict rights, freedoms and guarantees - achievements of the European project, which are truly defining the social pact of our societies.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. – The EU plays an important role in the fight against covid-19 and its consequences. The Danish Social Democrats are therefore very pleased that it has been possible to agree on ambitious economic aid packages for the Member States. And it is gratifying when Danish tripartite negotiations on wage compensation inspire the launch of SURE. At the same time, we are pleased that the EUROPEAN Union has taken the lead in coordinating the procurement of protective equipment and medical devices, that pan-European stocks are being built up to prepare for future health crises, and that 'green corridors' have been set up at border crossings so that European citizens do not experience shortages of goods and so that our health workers continue to receive vital equipment.  Although health policy is largely a national issue and must remain so, EU cooperation can support member states' management of the pandemic and, through sensible decisions, mitigate the long-term economic consequences. That is why we support the joint motion for a resolution.  However, the resolution is not without its problems. It is very worrying when the current crisis is being exploited to push for deeper EU integration. It's not the time. We also reserve the unequivocal support for increasing the overall framework of the MFF and the proposal for pan-European bonds.

name: Andrey SLABAKOV
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, I am very disappointed by the chaotic reaction of the European Parliament during the crisis. Hundreds of thousands are currently fighting for their lives and their bread, and we need to discuss concrete and reasonable measures to help them. I welcome the release of over EUR 3 trillion to combat the pandemic and rebuild the economy. That's reasonable. They probably won't make it, but at least it's a start. However, I cannot understand this obsession with the Green Pact and its implementation. Wake up! We already live in her world – we have no flights, the streets are empty and life has stopped. Many of you, dear colleagues, have suggested that we put the Green Pact as the backbone of our new economy and concentrate our finances in it, but no one mentioned the culture and artists who are currently suffering the most. I want to remind you that culture is the area that suffered first from the pandemic and will begin to recover last. The measures proposed so far are far from sufficient. Culture and artists are the heart and soul of Europe, do not let them perish while pursuing "green" dreams.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: in writing. – No European country is immune from the devastating consequences of the COVID-19 virus, and the response to the pandemic requires a truly European approach. One of the most important lessons is that we have a lot of work to do to ensure the coordination of the health systems of the Member States. We must act, as a Union, to ensure that in the future such a crisis never affects any of the Member States so strongly. This means constantly monitoring the performance of health systems in the Member States, improving the ability to manage risks and optimising crisis response. There is also an urgent need for a European Health Response Mechanism that can intervene quickly when vital materials and equipment are missing in one of Europe's regions. Mutual support at European level is the only solution, as shown by the creation of the first strategic reserve of medical equipment within the rescEU. The second major lesson of this crisis is that we can only respond effectively by preserving our European identity. Even in a state of emergency, we must remain true to the values that are part of European DNA. The rule of law, freedom of information, freedom of the press and transparency of decisions cannot be sacrificed.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. – Today's plenary debate is about the crisis caused by the coronavirus epidemic and the European response to it. In such a critical situation, when debating and deciding on high-priority issues, particular attention should be given to the functioning of the law and the rule of law. We cannot base the attacks on the fact that our operations are not predictable or in line with applicable law. Like all institutions, the institutions of the European Union must operate according to pre-laid rules and lawfully. This is set out in Article 2 of the Treaty, which provides the basis for the functioning of both the Union and the Member States. This requirement also applies to the European Parliament. In my opinion, the current method of sitting and voting chosen by the Bureau does not satisfy the aspects of legality, as it is contrary to the Treaties and the House legislation. Illegal operation may result in the invalidity of the decisions taken, causing serious legal uncertainty. The Union cannot afford to challenge the legal validity of its decisions, especially in today's lack of legitimacy. I trust that, taking into account my previous proposals in this regard, the European Parliament will take the necessary measures as soon as possible to restore legal functioning in order to avoid any future disputes.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: Writing. - Everything's changed. This is no longer just about GDP or economic growth: it is about our lives and our lives. We're going to put a lot of energy into defeating the virus. For this reason, too, I am very sorry that my initiative to set up a Special Committee on Covid-19, proposed by the Hungarian People's Party delegation and supported by the European People's Party, was not finally incorporated in the European Parliament's joint motion for a resolution. I still believe that it is important that dialogue between economic operators and the EP is more effective. It is essential that we can stimulate investment and job creation in the long term. Debates on this should be conducted through a specific platform. In order to avoid permanent damage to our way of life, we need to learn to work together in the current situation and think about how we can defeat the coronavirus and shorten the duration of the economic downturn. Although we do not yet see exactly the extent of the damage, it is already certain that the negative effects will be long-lasting, and the ideological debates that some of my fellow Members have had in recent weeks have unfortunately not brought the common cause further: the importance of effective and swift defence. The European Union should step up its efforts to provide the fastest and most effective assistance to countries in need.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing. – The current epidemic situation has also proofed that future action is needed, regardless of the ‘sacredness’ of Member State competences. It is intolerable that the health and quality of life of European citizens depends in particular on the given Member State of the Union they live in. National governments and the European Commission have to strength their resolve and collaboration at EU level to combat the COVID-19 outbreak. They have to adequately plan the recovery phases and better anticipate and manage future health emergencies. We need to develop a coherent set of guidelines and evidence-based strategies on the clinical management of COVID-19 during the emergency and recovery phases. And we have to ensure a future European health response mechanism which will encompass an EU coordinated intensive care strategy that will oversee the timely and consistent supply of treatments, diagnostic tests, medical and technological equipment and at the same time involving doctors, experts and healthcare professionals and healthcare organisations in advisory panels and coordination groups at European level. We need the same standards, and we need the European Minimum Health Service in every Member State.

name: Monika VANA
text: Writing. – In its response to the Corona Crisis, the European Parliament, as part of the European peace project, must be the body that, during crisis management, ensures that Member States uphold human rights and prevent authoritarian excesses. Attacks on justice and human rights are now the order of the day. The European Parliament must counter these attacks and ensure that Member States take the hard-won European Convention on Human Rights seriously and take responsibility and ensure the rule of law. The situation in Poland, Hungary and Greece is worrying. No government can use the Corona crisis to underpin human rights and democracy. It is our job to ensure that Europe acts in solidarity and offers protection to all people who are in Europe in these difficult times. The incitement against minorities and increasing homophobia must end in Europe based on solidarity. Women must have the right to have an abortion safely and legally. Refugees must be cared for and Greece must not be left alone on the refugee issue. The EU must put a stop to victor Orban's dismantling of democracy and the rule of law in Hungary. The Corona crisis must not be a wheel for a backlash.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Written. – The consequences of the corona crisis can only be addressed at European level. This has become crystal clear after the savage border closures and export bans. Just as clear is that it is easier to issue a lockdown than to get out. The fundamental interdependence of our societies and economy ensures that one measure can have unintended effects on other areas of society. Not only is a coordinated approach necessary, but the nature of the measures will also be crucial.  The joint resolution makes two things clear. First, most of the proposals are not new, but deal with known problems that were never taken for lack of political courage or national selfishness: closing the digital divide, protecting workers in precarious professions, robust social safety nets, introducing eurobonds. Now old prejudices must be destroyed and steps must be taken towards a Europe that protects its citizens. Secondly, the discussion of the job is that there would be no money to implement the Green Deal. It is now important to use these resources smartly in the transition to a circular, sustainable and fair economy. The Green Deal is a sustainable growth strategy. Just what we need.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: Writing. – Broad European cooperation and eu coordination of individual member states' actions are a prerequisite for an effective fight against the coronavirus epidemic. The European Parliament's decision to combat the coronavirus epidemic makes concrete proposals for a number of joint actions, the implementation of which would be a meaningful step forward in order to recap the current serious situation. Unfortunately, however, the decision contains a number of ideological and untrue statements about crisis management measures in Hungary. The reality, however, is that Hungary has so far failed to pass a law to control the new coronavirus outbreak, which would be contrary to either his own Constitution or EUROPEAN Union law, which was subsequently supported by the Vice-President of the European Commission in a statement. Unlike many other EU Member States, the Hungarian Parliament has very strong control powers in the event of an emergency and the deadline for crisis management measures specifically ends with the end of the crisis situation. We are in a crisis of unprecedented size, where we should be focusing all our efforts on controlling the epidemic, not on ideologically based, un-based and double-standard accusations. I cannot therefore support this decision by my vote.

name: Marianne VIND
text: Written. – The EU plays an important role in the fight against covid-19 and its consequences. The Danish Social Democrats are therefore very pleased that it has been possible to agree on ambitious economic aid packages for the Member States. And it is gratifying when Danish tripartite negotiations on wage compensation inspire the launch of SURE. At the same time, we are pleased that the EUROPEAN Union has taken the lead in coordinating the procurement of protective equipment and medical devices, that pan-European stocks are being built up to prepare for future health crises, and that 'green corridors' have been set up at border crossings so that European citizens do not experience shortages of goods and so that our health workers continue to receive vital equipment. Although health policy is largely a national issue and must remain so, EU cooperation can support member states' management of the pandemic and, through sensible decisions, mitigate the long-term economic consequences. That is why we support the joint motion for a resolution.  However, the resolution is not without its problems. It is very worrying when the current crisis is being exploited to push for deeper EU integration. It's not the time. We also reserve the unequivocal support for increasing the overall framework of the MFF and the proposal for pan-European bonds.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – Mr President, the coronavirus crisis has put the importance of self-sufficiency and security of supply at the centre in a new way. At its most extreme, it is currently reflected in the world's dependence on China's capacity to manufacture critically important protective equipment and breathing apparatus. As a result of the crisis, Europe will have to reassess its own security of supply and global production chains. There are a number of sectors in industry where Europe is heavily dependent on imported materials and components. Global production chains are long today and often not transparent to companies themselves. In Europe, as a result of the crisis, many industrial companies have had to close down due to a shortage of components, as mobility restrictions around the world have put long production and logistics chains on hold. There is no point in pursuing full self-sufficiency, but Europe should be able to ensure the continuity of critical production even in different exceptional circumstances. The coronavirus crisis is a big lesson in that. Although the EU has taken into account the risks of energy dependency and electronic dependency in recent years, food production, the pharmaceutical industry or now access to critical protective equipment have not been sufficiently assessed from the point of view of security of supply. It is certain that as a result of the coronavirus crisis, global production chains will change. The EU must make a stronger effort towards European production, which will also be able to operate in exceptional circumstances. This may also contribute to accelerating the transition to a circular economy. The action plan for the new circular economy presented by the Commission in March, which aims to move from linear production chains to the circulation of materials and raw materials, would reduce dependence on critical imported raw materials. It would be effective both from an economic and environmental point of view.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Writing. The European Union is facing the biggest economic crisis in its history. In order to cushion this, I am voting today in the European Parliament for billions of dollars in emergency aid. This financial support for our European economy is right and necessary. However, we must now ask ourselves how we can finance these aid packages in the long term without passing on the costs to the most vulnerable members of our society. In order to prevent the poorest people from paying the bill for the Corona crisis after the crisis, we finally need European tax justice. The EU loses EUR 825 billion of taxpayers' money every year through tax avoidance of large international corporations and tax fraud through criminal activities of individuals – this must stop. Over the next few years, this money could not only finance the much-needed Corona emergency aid, but also enable necessary investments, for example in health care or climate protection. To this end, we must finally take concrete measures at European level to close European tax loopholes and work together to stop the methods of fraudsters. I therefore call on the Commission to act and take concrete steps to prevent tax avoidance in the EU. The way out of the crisis must not be a way back to tax avoidance!

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: Writing. – There can be no doubt that Europe is in the midst of the biggest post-war crisis. However, the resolution tabled brings only ideology and does not reflect the real development of the situation. Member States' significantly different approaches to the pandemic have revealed that decision-making at a lower, people-understandable level provides the possibility to react more flexibly and quickly. And national borders became more important because some states immediately began lockdown, while others long adhered to the theory of herd immunity. It is therefore not appropriate to request a further transfer of competences and financial resources to the Union institutions, nor to criticise the Member States for acting in their own way and in the interests of their citizens, and not waiting for instructions from the Centre when taking the necessary measures and providing medical supplies. The multiannual financial framework deserves a major overhaul to meet the EU's post-pandemic needs, but the aim should not be to increase costs endlessly just to meet pre-crisis ambitions for carbon neutrality. The Green Deal is a program of costly restructuring of the economy and abandonment of entire industries. And at a time of global economic downturn, it will lead to further decline of already decimated national economies and further strengthening China's global standing. Let us support joint efforts, but let us limit the EU's ambitions to manage everything.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. – The deadly pandemic we are experiencing has proved that we are all just as weak in the face of the enemy. The Greek government showed determination and quick reflexes in the management of the crisis, which was recognized internationally. Despite the decade-long debt crisis that has adstanced my country and Turkey's consistently aggressive immigration policy, Greece has been brave and acted effectively in the face of an international problem, pointing the way to large and powerful countries. The health crisis knocked on everyone's door and exhausted even the most robust economies.  We welcome the economic measures taken by the Union to support European countries, but we need more than ever even stronger solidarity in practice. Now is the time for decisive policies, which will not divide the European North and the South, but will lead to a massive recovery and joint responsibility. The issue of a European bond will provide the necessary support to tackle the pandemic and its consequences.  In these difficult times the minds of all of us lie in those who fight on the front line and fight an unequal battle with the invisible enemy. We owe our deepest gratitude to these people and extend our deepest condolences to the families of the victims.

name: Veronika VRECIONOVÁ
text: Writing. – I cannot support the draft joint resolution on combating the coronavirus. Instead of the really necessary steps to help stop the spread of the virus while helping the economy, this resolution has been used to call for further devolution from nation states to EU level. It was the nation-states that were fighting the coronavirus. In many cases successfully, in many unsuccessful cases. The problem of these failed countries cannot be solved by getting rid of responsibility and moving it to EU level. Let us stop offering as one single miracle cure for any crisis by strengthening the EU's powers. That's not the way. Paradoxically, some statements by representatives of the European Commission, on the contrary, further discourage the citizens of the Czech Republic from eu membership. And that's not in our best interest.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – COVID-19 has exposed the weakness of the EU institutions, which have not taken swift and coordinated action to protect citizens' public health. He laid bare how irresponsible it is to push for a liberal approach to health care management and how painful the consequences of pharmaceutical companies and the production of medical equipment outside the EU are. As a result, hospitals today lack ventilators and life-saving medical equipment, as well as the necessary personal protective equipment.  A symbol of the Helplessness of the Community is the dramatic appeal of the Italian public, which has been turning to the EU for weeks for help. The EC's first response to the pandemic was belated and the proposed measures were insufficient in view of the scale of the challenges facing pandemic-sacted Europe today. The burden of fighting the coronavirus has fallen on the shoulders of the Member States. Some are doing better in this situation, as is Poland, others are doing worse.  In the face of the increasing number of people and victims, as well as the economic impact of the crisis, we do not need words of solidarity, we need concrete, urgent action. Nor is it a time for political attacks. Those who, even during the pandemic, do not give up their constant attack on the Polish and Hungary are doing so. We are on the front lines of the fight, but it cannot be a political fight. The time has come for us to learn from this crisis that the EU will be able to ensure the health security of citizens in the future.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Writing. – We are at a time of one of the biggest crises, health, social and economic. This crisis has affected all EU countries and has called for measures that none of us could have imagined until recently. Individual countries and their governments acted quickly and according to current needs. I am glad that they informed each other of their actions and coordinated them. Whether it was at European Council meetings or in a multilateral way. They were able to show a great deal of solidarity, sending protective equipment, medical supplies, helping themselves to the repatriation of their citizens and recruiting patients.  I am all the more sorry about the resolution tabled. It does not reflect reality and is mired in a traditional Eurofederalist dream of a more integrated and centralist EU. Instead of looking at ways in which the EU can actually help Member States and citizens, we are dealing with more powers for the European Commission that it does not need and a larger budget, which member countries will eventually have to pay. And, of course, it continues to cling to the policies of the new Green Deal, the costly restructuring of the economy and society as a whole. There is no need for Brussels to be the centre of the world and the EU always has to play first fiddle at all costs. On the contrary, the strength of our cooperation is precisely that the Member States can respond more quickly, flexibly and better to specific situations and problems. We must work together and deal with some things together, but there is no reason to centralise and unify everything.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The joint resolution under discussion in the European Parliament demonstrates the broad consensus between the representatives of the peoples of the Union on a strong, coordinated and solidarity response to the pandemic, in terms of health, economic, social and environmental. I would like to like to support the proposed enhanced cooperation measures in the field of health, including strengthening the competences of european agencies and establishing a European health emergency response mechanism. I also point out the call for the strengthening of all coordination mechanisms in crisis management. The creation of an additional fund for research and development in the field of innovative medicines and vaccines to tackle COVID19 is also a very meritorious proposal. In mitigating the economic and social impact, the proposal that the funds made available by the funding lines approved by the Eurogroup should not have negative conditionalities and also apply to the economic and social consequences of the pandemic is essential. The joint issuance of bonds to finance the recovery plan is crucial, as is the proposal to strengthen and adapt the Multiannual Financing Framework to the new circumstances. Finally, I underline the focus on the European ecological pact and the digital transition as recovery levers.
